characters: ENDLESS, SILKY, DESERT MOUNTAINS AT SUNSET. 128
JOINS IN WITH HARMONY AND BEAT...
THE RINGING ECHOES IN HER HALLWAY.
THE MODERATE RISE AND TRAGIC FALL OF A NEW YORK FIXER
FESTIVE CROWD OF DIPLOMATES, DIGNITARIES AND JOURNALISTS
TAGS, BUSINESS CARDS CHANGING HANDS, MEN AND WOMEN IN
HAPPY FARMERS HARVESTING RICH LAND, PICKING PERFECT ORANG
VERY SWEET VOICED CANTOR SINGING THIS PRAYER
A CAMEL AND OLD CITY JERUSALEM IN THE BACK GROUND
THE EVENING. MEN, WOMEN, OLD AND YOUNG, NAME, ORGANIZATIO
FLASHES OF PEOPLE INTRODUCING THEMSELVES TO NORMAN EARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is still dark outside. The CNN clock over Columbus Circle shows: 5:25am. NORMAN OPPENHEIMER (60) is standing next to a_bench Central Park. He has EARPHONES in both ears. In his hand notice a METAL BUSINESS CARD HOLDER. At this hour it is either fitness fanatics or true workaholics who need to be in the office by 7am, exercisi in the park. Norman is watching these fanatics pass by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shot of a PEN writing on a_| PAPER NAPKIN: It is a diag with lines and circles that loosely follows the names, numbers and institutions as we hear them:

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is the idea, the Israeli government is withholding about three hundred million dollars of tax receivables from the Palestinian Authority. My idea is to find someone here, someone like Jo Wilf, or an Arthur Taub, who would buy that debt. Pay the Palestinians eighty or ninety cents on_the dollar, assuming that the Palestinians will take what they can get at this point, and that the Israeli government would have no choice but to honor their debt to an American financial institution. We see PHILIP COHEN (40) listening to Norman in a crowded Starbucks with a polite but very skeptical look on his fa

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (passing the napkin to Philip) Everybody wins. The Palestinians get their money. Israel isn’t making any political concessions, and lets say it is Wilf - he collects thirty or forty million or worst case scenario - just the interest for that debt.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Why would the Palestinians agree to get less than the full amount?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Because it is better than getting nothing. Philip thinks about this for a moment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: That is actually a pretty good idea.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: It is. I've thought it through. I just need someone who can do it. (pointing at Wilf’s name on the napkin Isn't this the scale of the kind of deals Wilf is looking for? A tight shot of Norman in Central Park, smiling, recallin this conversation with Philip. There is a strange excitem in his expression. He pulls the earphones out of his ears Then back to:

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Yes, but I don’t know if he would get involved in a political situation like this... I mean, I know he wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: All I_want_to do is present it to him. I really think it serves everyone. When something is good, it’s good. This is good.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I don’t have direct contact with Wilf. You know that, right?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: But you have friends there. Don’t you? This is your circle... Philip has to consider this for a moment. NORMAN cour’ D) If you're not comfortable doing this, I’1l understand. I can ask a few other people I know... But I wanted to show it to you first.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Bill Kavish. Do you know him? He works for Wilf. He is a friend. Have you heard his name?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Maybe. Why do I know that name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to Norman. One of the runners he sees is BILL KAVISH(35). We follow Bill, FROM NORMAN’S POV, as he finishes his run stops by a tree to stretch his muscles. We focus in on Bill’s energized face as we continue to he

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You know his family. His father was Henry Kavish. You remember him? He was a fund-raiser for Ort in the Eighties. He got into some kind of trouble. They caught him Shactly some money. I don’t know exact what happened there, but. they fi fired him, his wife left him, his kid: turned their backs on him. He died alone and penniless. Bill is his youngest son. Norman is fixated on Bill’s face, his movement, studying with genuine human interest, as if looking for the emotio scar his father left on him. Norman has taken out one of his BUSINESS CARDS, holding i between his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to Philip and Norman.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Can you introduce me to Bill?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I haven't spoken to him in a long time...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: There is nothing to lose. If he is not interested, he'll say he is not interested... But if he is... You never know...

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I can give you Bill’s e-mail, but I'd prefer not to send a formal introduction. We represent clients who do business with them... I don’t want to be in a position where I’m asking him for a favor.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: You're doing him a favor... But okay. That's Fine. Can I say we are related? Can I say I’m your uncle? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: No. Don’t make it a family thing. It doesn’t sound good... It might not be a good idea to mention my name. Norman clearly needs more than that. And Philip has to gi him something.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can say you know me. But please don’t tell him you got his address from me. Norman nods his head with polite gratitude. Philip senses distress as he gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I can’t be more helpful. It’s tough. You’re like a drowning man waving at an ocean-liner. How do you get it to see you? Jo Wilf is an ocean-liner. He doesn’t see any of us...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: But I’m a good swimmer. Don’t forget that. As long as my head is above water, I know how to tread. With a pat on Norman's back, Philip leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re back at the park where Bill, still stretching, noti Norman staring at him. Norman raises his hand in an innoc friendly gesture. Bill has no idea who he is. He nods his head and continue stretching, a bit suspicious of the friendly stranger. Norman approaches him, handing him his BUSINESS CARD.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Good morning, Bill. Norman Oppenheimer.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What the fuck? You’re stalking me now??

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I only need a few minutes of your time. I know you are busy. Philip Cohen might have mentioned me...

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: No. Excuse me. This is my private time... please respect that. Call the office. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I’m in touch with your secretary twice a day. Very nice lady, but You don’t return my calls. What am I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Let it go! Give up. Does Philip know you're here? How did you even find me?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: It’s a good business opportunity, Why should I let it go? I wouldn't be here if it wasn’t time sensitive. Just give me a minute to explain. A very igh official, I can’t mention his name right now, came to me with an offer to sell his country’s tax receivables to a third party... Bill can’t believe he’s in this situation. He looks at No as if he is a crazy man.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eighty cents on the dollar...

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I have to leave... Excuse me. This is unacceptable.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (as Bill walks awa Bill, I wouldn’t be doing this if I didn't think it is worth ’Jo’s time. Don’t trust me, trust Philip. Sometimes good things come in surprising ways... You never know... You never know, right? Worse comes to worse, he kicks me out the door...

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (turning around) No - worse comes to worse, he kicks ME out the door. It’s my job to keep peopie like you away. Don’t you get that? Please, respect my position. Stop: Just stop. I’m sorry. But I don’t know what else to say. Bill waits to see if Norman is internalizing the finality his response.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: So I’ll tell my partners we had a good conversation... and we’ll see what happens. Okay? Bill shakes his head with disbelief and walks away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORMAN (CONT’D) Thank you, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is standing across the street from a DINER called BROOKLYN DINER at the floor of a huge office building. He is looking through the windows of the diner at Bill Kavish, now dressed in his business suit, sitting with a other businessmen in one of the booths. The man in the ce of this Breakfast gathering is JO WILF (70), authoritativ calm, allowing the younger men around him to do all the talking. Norman pulls out his phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I got a meeting! INT. PHILIP’S OFFICE - SAME TIME 10

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: With Jo Wilf?? Right before Norman answers, Bill Kavish raises his eyes catches Norman’s glance, standing outside. Bill give hima viciously protective look.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Better. With Arthur Taub. We sense that Philip doesn’t believe Norman.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: If Jo Wilf is an ocean-liner, Arthur is a nuclear submarine... How did you manage that?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (walking away) I told you, I’m a good swimmer. Our view expands to see Norman walking away and blending the Midtown bustle. This image gradually goes out of focu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman walks into this vast, intimidating lobby. He approaches a reception desk underneath a sign that rea “Barclays Oil and Gas Exploration Conference” Norman causally stands in line with a few other business people waiting to register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman has a name-tag over his chest pocket. It reads: NO

dialogues.speaker: OPPENHEIMER
dialogues.text: He wanders into a medium size auditorium in the middle of panel discussion, quietly finding a seat in the back of t room. THE ROOM IS FULL OF BANKERS AND FINANCE EXECUTIVES. From distance Norman blends in, but a closer look at how he is dressed, exposes that he clearly does not belong. On stage, with a backdrop of images of massive oil drilli rigs, there is a MODERATOR and a GUEST SPEAKER-- RON MAOR(65) a minister in the Israeli Parliament. They are discussing geopolitics and the energy market, bu our focus is Norman’s POV, scanning the room. He is hunting for something, focusing on different individuals, men and women, their name-tags, their japtop gadgets, briefcases, shoes, different items that catch hi attention. While in the B.G.

dialogues.speaker: RON MAOR
dialogues.text: (heavy Israeli accent) I told the American leadership, at a very high level, probably more than half a year ago. Go to the Russians. They hold the keys. They know the commanders of these units of chemical warfare on a first name basis. Some of them are married to Russian women. The most effective way to protect this potentially dangerous arsenal, is by getting into contact with the Russians. But it should be a real contact without a drop of arrogance. Understanding in advance that, okay, America lead in Iraq, Europe lead in Libya, now ask the Russians to lead and acce) the fact that they will have a cote in resolving this conflict.

dialogues.speaker: MODERATOR
dialogues.text: Suppose someone says you can’t trust them. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MODERATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You would say it is not a matter of trust but of national interest... Norman has fished a MIKE AND IKE candy out of his coat pocket. He sucks on it without calling attention to himse

dialogues.speaker: MAOR
dialogues.text: There is clearly a problem, it relates to the Chinese and the Far East as well. It is a major question in the next decade for all the other allies around the Pacific Rim. Is America pushing Russia away from the West and into the arms of China? Some natural gas experts in this room will say that is exactly what _they’re doing by encouraging a pipeline between Israel and Turkey. Inevitably you will have a symbiotic relationship with China, based on currency trade, whatever... But as I always say, when dealing with global interests, we shouldn’t be playing backgammon, shesh-besh, you know. Where you roll the dice and hope for the best. We should be playing chess. As this is going on, Norman has locked his glance on: MICHA ESHEL. He is in his mid 40s, handsome, well dressed. He is sitti in the front row near the door, with an expression that i saying that he has heard all this before and that he is n very impressed with Mr. Maor on stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A buffet lunch is being served. The ATTENDEES are minglin Maor is the center of the room, everyone is trying to get word with him. But there is a SMALLER GROUP OF PEOPLE greeting Eshel as on the other side of the room. It_is as if these two important men, Eshel and Maor, whil polite to each other and perfectly pleasant, are actually apposing teams. Norman is following this dynamic very carefully, noticing they elegantly avoid eye contact with each other. At a certain point Maor is escorted out of the room by hi security guards and entourage. Eshel watches Maor leave. While Norman is watching Eshel.  15 16 17 18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is now three-quarters empty. In this panel, Micha Eshel is the main attraction. He speaks with much less pathos and with considerable hum and ease. THE FEW PEOPLE that stayed to hear him, seem to enjoy his sarcasm. Norman is sitting in the back, listeni

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: The distinguished minister speaking before me, who I have a great deal of respect for, seems to know a lot about everything, and it is hard to argue with him... god forbid, I’m not saying he is wrong... China, Russia, America... He must know what he is talking about. He is my boss, after all. And a very good chess player. (slightest smile. Audience laughs) But you know, George Bernard Shaw once said - some people see the way things are and ask why. I see how things should be and ask - why not?! Mr. Maor is very good at describing the world as it is. If you ask me, I think our job is to discuss how the world should be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eshel is acceptin compliments | from the few people who a walking with him toward the exit. Norman is tailing behind. He follows Eshel out the doors, watching him as he says goodbye to all the people around him - ‘surprisingly remaining all alone on the Midtown sidewalk, without any entourage or security. Eshel puts on his sunglasses takes in the busy street as if deciding where to go, then heads Uptown. Nozman peels off his name-tag from his jacket and follows Eshel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eshel stops at a traffic light. Norman is close behind hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eshel has entered a gourmet chocolate store. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Norman carefully peeks into the store window to see Eshel casually sampling chocolate. Norman considers going inside, but there is something intimate in the way Eshel is savoring the chocolate that Norman knows would embarrass Eshel if interrupted. So Norman waits outside as Eshel moves over to the cashie with a bag of MILK CHOCOLATE COVERED CASHEWS. Norman quickly ducks out of Eshel’s eye-line

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From inside the shop and its exquisitely designed display window, we see out toward Madison Ave. Different Upper East Side types cross the window. Then Eshel stops by the window. He looks inside at a pair BEAUTIFUL CALFSKIN SHOES set on a pedestal. The shoes are centerpiece of the window display. He is munching out of a his BAG OF CHOCOLATES. Then we see NORMAN walk by the shop. Norman looks at Eshel for a moment, making believe he is recognizing him for the first time. Eshel turns around. Norman introduces himself. They shake hands. They talk for a bit. They are referring to somethi in the display window. Norman is laughing. So is Eshel. They stop laughing and continue conversing about somethin both of them seem to agree on. Eshel offers Norman a chocolate from his bag. Norman firm declines. Then Norman opens the door to the shop and allo Eshel to enter before him. Only now do we hear them, mid conversation:

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: -.-I’d be hap ppy to introduce you to him. Let me tell Arthur you are in town. I’m going to his dinner tonight. You can join me.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: How do you know Arthur Taub?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: wy wife used to baby-sit him. Then e ended up working for him, years later. They were very close. (pulling out his cell phone) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me tell him you’re here, I’m sure he would be happy if you came tonight. Eshel examines Norman’s face. His ghothing - His hair. Th is something about his appearance that makes Eshel want t think this over.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Hold on a second. Put the phone back... Norman puts the phone back in his pocket. THE SALES PERSO who has been waiting for an opening in their conversation greets the two gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: SALES PERSON
dialogues.text: Good Morning. Welcome to Lanvin. My name is Jacques.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: We are just looking around for now. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: I am very happy to assist you today... Come inside.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Eshel is speaking at a very special event later this week and has a series of meetings with business leaders and diplomats. He would like to try on the shoes in the window. Jacques puts his hand under his chin and looks at Eshel, taking in the clothing he is currently wearing and his general style. Eshel humors him by posing with his hands folded under hi chest.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: May I ask what line of business you are in?

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I don’t want to ruin my good first impression, but I am a politician.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Micha Eshel. He is the minister of trade and labor in Israel and deputy to the prime minister.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: No. I’m the deputy minister of trade and labor. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My boss, the minister, is a deputy to the prime minister, but there are three other deputies, just to put things in context.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: It is an honor to meet you, Sir. I’m sorry, but you looked too young to be... so important.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Thank you for the very flattering lie, You have a future in politics... which is more than I can say for myself. I might be young, but I’m already washed up. I’m just kidding. Very nice to meet you, Jacques.

dialogues.speaker: ____ JACQUES
dialogues.text: §gincerely You don’t look washed up.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Thank you. That’s because I’m in New York now. New York makes me feel good. Back home, I look tired.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No you don’t. I’ve seen your appearances on TV. You look great.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: That is because I’m very photogenic...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No, you are one of the few Israeli politicians who radiates optimism.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Optimism... The shoes I buy today will last longer than the government I serve in.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Change is good. That’s what I was told.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: The fashion world relies on change.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: And the Middle East relies on - how do you say stagnatzia?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Stagnation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Stagnation. Once you’re in power, you don’t want anything to change. You can ask my boss about that...

dialogues.speaker: ORMAN,
dialogues.text: Do you think he'll become prime minister?

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Maor? If he does, It’1ll be a joke.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: What about you? Would you ever consider running?

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Me? (eating a chocolate) You know what the problem with modern leadership is? To be a real leader, you need to have a firm idealogy, you have to really know what is right, and never look to the sides... (illustrating with his hand) Straight. But in order to get elected, you need to be the opposite of all that. That’s the tricky part.

dialogues.speaker: ORMAN
dialogues.text: Something tells me that you can do both hink you would be a great candidate.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Only magicians can do two things at the same time. (to Jacques) So what do you say?

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: The event you are attending... It is in the evening, yes?

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Yes. But I think people will be coming straight from work. I don’t think they’re getting dressed up especially for this.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Of course they are. It’s not black tie, but this is going to be a classy crowd. It’s at the Waldorf Astoria. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eshel has casually picked up a shoe to see the price. We it as well: $1045! NORMAN (CONT’D) (to Jacques) The press will be there too...

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: (returning the shoe) Forget the shoes. Nobody is going to be looking at my shoes. Maybe, can I see your ties... He walks over to the tie display.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: What size shoe are you? A ten? Eleven? Just try them on. We’re already here.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: No. I’m not getting shoes now. (picking up a beautiful tie)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (handing the shoe to Jacques ) We'll try these on for Mr. Eshel. Jacques walks over to one of the racks, looking for something.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: I think I have a better idea. take some measurements, Mr. she >

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: No. Really, I don’t want to take up your time. Thank you. How much is this tie? Norman moves in closer to Eshel, taking the tie from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Let’s see what he comes up with. Don’t say no before you try it on. (reassuring him with eye contact) Don’t worry. Trust me. Enjoy it. Let him do his job.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: A young minister should not feel washed up. Excuse me for saying. Please... I can help with this. Let me try something. Eshel thinks about this for a brief moment, then playfull submits himself to Jacques’ tape measure. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Norman, in the meantime, sneaks a peek at the price tag o the tie: $195!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eshel is now standing with his back to a set of THREE MIRRORS. He is dressed in a new elegant suit, shirt and t He looks, and more importantly - FEELS amazing. It is not flashy, it does not call too much attention to itself, bu does give him a uniqueness that Eshel can feel even witho seeing himself. Norman is reflected in all 3 mirrors, smiling. Jacques is kneeling by Eshel’s feet, fixing his cuff.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: (to Norman) So you said your wife works for Arthur Taub?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Used to work for him, yes. She passed away.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: This was years ago. But she was very close to Arthur and I would be more than happy if you joined me tonight. He is someone you should meet...

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I’ve been hearing his name from a few different people recently. He's young, right? What’s he like?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (expertly) There are two kinds of moguls. One kind is like a big ocean-liner ship, they make a lot of waves, and noise, everybody can see them from miles away... Like Jo Wilf. I think Minister Maor is in his close circle of friends. Eshel takes note of that last point. NORMAN (CONT’D) And then there is Arthur, who is more like a nuclear submarine. Quiet. Fast. Young. And extremely sophisticated. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Interesting...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: He’s an interesting fellow. He likes to surround Rimselt with consultants who are in influential political positions but with an eye on the future. He has good instincts about these things. And he is very good about compensating his consultants. You’d enjoy meeting him. Eshel takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: SHEL
dialogues.text: Maybe I’11 have my office contact him. We’ll see... I’m not a private person, you know... Not yet, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Of course. But if you need ny help reaching him, I’m happy to do it. Even if it is just to plant a seed...

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Where are you staying while you are here? How can I reach you? We sense Eshel doesn’t want to answer that question. He l over at Norman, again trying to evaluate him. Jacques at this point has helped him slip on a pair of surprisingly simple looking shoes with a metallic brown t to them and ordinary laces.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Can I look at myself yet?

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: Please, Mr. Eshel, you can turn around now. Eshel turns around to look at himself. He is speechless. The 3 mirrors create a triptych with the reflections of E and Norman in his background. Eshel, looking carefully at his reflected image, tries a facial expression that 1s contemplative and serious. Then fills his lungs with air, creating a more authoritative impression. Norman and Jacques are watching Eshel transform into what always imagined he could be. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But then Eshel looks down at the price tag on the suit jacket. We see it as well: $6750!! Then at the shirt price tag: $635!! Eshel takes off the jacket as if it were on fire and hand to the surprised Jacques. He then takes off the shoes and pulls off his pants.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Please, take all this away from me before I get used to it. You are right, it does make me feel fabulous, but there is one rule every Israeli politician learns in the beginning of his career: you cannot wear a suit that costs more than an ordinary man’s car. Israelis don’t want to see their representatives enjoying themselves. That is a fact. I’m sorry for wasting your time.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: But what if you didn’t know how much it costs?

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I do. It is too late.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: to Jacques) Could Mr. Eshel perhaps borrow the suit for his event?

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: I can ask. We do that occasionally with celebrities and red carpets.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: No! I’m not borrowing it. I don’t want to feel like Cinderella for one night. I’m not a model, I'ma member of parliament.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Then keep the shoes.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: (handing the shoes to Jacques ) No. Enough... I don’t want them. Norman takes the shoes from Jacques.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Please. Let me buy you these shoes. It would be my privilege to buy them for you. If it makes an Israeli leader feel good, that is the least I can do. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: No. Thank you. But no. I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (kneeling by Eshel with the shoes) Would you at least put them on one more time. Go ahead. Just put your feet inside, before you say no. Eshel looks at Jacques, then at Norman, and finally slips feet back into the shoes. Eshel is now in his shirt, tie, underwear, socks and - metallic brown dress shoes. He lov these shoes! Norman pulls out his CREDIT CARD and gives i Jacques. NORMAN (CONT’D) We're taking them. I don’t want you walking out of here empty handed...

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: (intercepting the card) I can’t let you pay. If I take the shoes, I have to pay for them.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: It’s an expense for me. I write it off. Don’t argue... I want to do it.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: The truth is, I can’t put that kind of expense on my credit card.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: You don’t have to. I got it. Norman pushes Eshel’s hand away, nods to Jacques, who tak moment to confirm the transaction before he steps into a room with the credit card.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah? You sure?

dialogues.speaker: _. NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Positive. Don’t worry. I’m happy to do it. Eshel is looking down at Norman’s worn-out $40 shoes.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: What about you? Why don’t you buy a pair for Yourself? They really are magical shoes

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Me? No. I need special orthopedic shoes, I have a very wide foot. Don! t ask. I’ve got problematic eet... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jacques returns with the card and pen on a tray together the receipt. Norman blushes with surprise when he looks at the receipt before he signs it. We see the amount: $1137 (including t Norman picks up the pen to sign, but right before he does stops to look at Eshel who is putting on his old cloths.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Is everything okay? Norman signs the receipt. Places the pen down with a dram effect.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Everything is perfect! Enjoy!

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: Would you like to wear them out, Mr. Eshel, or should I put them in a box for you.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Please put them in a box. Thank you. I’ll save them for the right occasion. He hands the shoes to Norman as if Norman were his assist Norman hands the shoes over to Jacques to wrap in a box.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus. I just realized I’m terribly late. I must run now. Thank you very much. (then to Norman) I don’t know what to say. Thank you for this. I’m glad I bumped into you!

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: (joking) I should have taken the tie too...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Next time...

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Next time. (then...) Here, take the chocolates. They’re delicious.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I have severe nut allergies. One wrong bite and I can drop dead. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 1li ng thi bi (pulling the bag away) Oh. Sorry. Specifically cashews?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No. Peanuts. But this is the one area I don’t take any risks. Thank you for offering.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: (holding up a chocolate) This can really kill you? What happens if you take a bite?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: If it has even the smallest trace of a peanut, my body mistakes it for a dangerous substance and immediately shuts itself down. My skin reacts, My eyes tear. My nose starts running, and my throa swells so that I can’t breathe. Norman pulls out an EPIPEN injector from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I don’t inject myself with one of these, I can be dead in less than fifteen minutes. Eshel is impressed by this description. He pops the chocolate he was holding into his mouth and carefully places the bag of chocolates on the counter nex Jacques, away from Norman. Jacques nods with gratitude. Eshel walks toward the exit of the fitting room.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What about Arthur? Would you like to meet him? Can I tell him you’1l be coming with me tonight? Eshel thinks about this for a moment. Finally--

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Sure. Why not. It would be great to meet him. I just need to check my schedule. I’m staying at the Warwick. Leave a message for me there with the details. Thank you, Norman...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Norman Oppenheimer. Eshel walks back in, hands Norman his BUSINESS CARD, and him on his shoulder in a friendly way. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Here. Take this. It has my private number in back. No matter what, when you are in Israel, Norman Oppenheimer, if you ever peed anything, feel free to call. Norman pulls out his card holder and takes out his own business card and hands it to Eshel.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: And this is me. When you are in New York, if there is anything I can help "with, anything at all, please let me know. And I711 call you later.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: (reading off Norman’s card Oppenheimer Strategies... Eshel puts the card inside the shoe box. On his way out with his shopping bag, he grabs a few fina chocolates from the bag he left on the counter. Norman and Jacques watch him as he blends into Madison Av Norman looks down at the card in his hand. We see it has official symbol of the state of Israel. It reads: “MINISTRY OF INDUSTRY, TRADE AND LABOR. MICHA ESHEL, DEPUTY MINISTER”. And on the other side, handwritt Eshel’s PRIVATE CELL PHONE NUMBER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is walking and talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: -.-I understand it is a sit-down dinner. I don’t need a seat. Just one seat for Mr. Eshel. I’11 stand. I have to be somewhere anyway. Norman stops walking. Distressed. NORMAN (CONT’D Please, don’t give me a final answer until you speak with Arthur.- - Micha Eshel. -- E. S. H. E. L. Tell him he is the guy in charge of regulating the energy industry...-- My name? Norman Oppenheimer . -- M Eshel is a close friend of mine. -- Micha_is in town for a few days and he told me he would really love to meet Arthur... --Just please ask Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORMAN (CONT’D) And if there are two seats, that is obviously better...--One seat is enough. More than enough. See what you can do. Thank you. Call me ack...-- Thank you. Norman hangs up, pulls out Eshel’s business card and dial INT. ESHEL’S HOTEL SUITE BATHROOM - SAME TIME 22

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESHEL’S PHONE RINGS just as_he enters his suite. He looks the number on the screen, places the phone on a table by door and heads toward the luxurious tub in the bathroom. We stay on the phone while it continues to ring and Eshel gets the water running in the tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman gives up, dials another number. After a moment.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Hi. Can you connect me _to Mr. Eshel’s room... --So can I leave him a message? INT. ESHEL’S HOTEL SUITE - NIGHT - LATER 24

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eshel, in a robe, AND WEARING HIS NEW SHOES, is speaking the phone. With:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is seven hours ahead and DUBY (60s), Eshel’s lawyer, a small man with intense eyes and a no-nonsense demeanor, i in bed, picking up a pen and note-pad from his night-tabl THEY SPEAK HEBREW.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: (as he writes down the name Norman Oppenheimer) Did he say what he does?

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: He’s a businessman. He has some kind of investment fund. Not sure I understood exactly... A warm Jew. Duby is quietly stepping out of his bedroom so not to wak his wife, taking the pad with him.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: You want to meet Arthur Taub, but not through this guy Norman. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I have nothing better to do tonight, why not join him?

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: You can’t walk in there with someone you just met and know nothing about. These things are important. If you want to meet Arthur, let me set up a proper meeting.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Are you sure? It seems harmless... Duby by now is by his laptop, searching for NORMAN OPPENHEIMER. Random faces come up, but none of them are Norman. The further down he scrolis, the more pictures of ROBERT OPPENHEIMER and images of ATOMIC EXPLOSIONS fill t screen.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: I’m sure. One hundred percent sure. Eshel has walked out onto the terrace of the suite.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I hear Taub is like some kind of - nuclear submarine...

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Listen to me. We don’t even know what this event is all about... I don’t want you walking into an uncomfortable situation. Go see a movie. Go have a good meal. Should I_ reserve a table for you at a nice place?

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I'll find something to do. Forget it. Any press on my visit here so far? Duby is now looking at a NEWS WEBSITE on his computer scr with a picture of RON MAOR in a photo-opp in NY with important U.S. officials.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: No. Nothing special. It’s better this way...

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: It’s crazy to see how they suck up everything Maor says. I’m telling ou, he is a dangerous man. He iterally believes his own bullshit... As if he is running the entire world. Duby is sensing the poison spreading in Eshel’s veins and knows he needs to change the subject. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: (searching the web for entertainment options) Do you want to see a show tonight? What do you feel like doing?

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: ...I don’t understand how people take him seriously? Can’t they see he is as dumb as a shoe?

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: I’m getting you tickets for a show!

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: No show. I’m not in the mood for a show. I'll go get something to eat. Don’t worry about me...

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Okay. Put it on your hotel bill. They’re paying for it. And do me a favor - stay away from the Normans. I’m serious. Duby disappears, we stay on Eshel. He sits down on the sofa in his suite. He is restless. His phone RINGS. He realizes it is Norman. He is tempted answer, but as per Duby’s instructions - he doesn’t. Instead, he picks up the remote control and turns on the as the phone continues to RING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman hangs up his phone. He is waiting by the entrance as INVITEES pass him on the way into a grand Upper East Side townhouse. He steps out to the street corner, but no sign of Eshel. He takes out his phone again. We see the screen. He is calling - “Eshel Private Cell.” It rings and rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eshel is sitting alone in a booth in a very expensive gou restaurant, sipping WINE and enjoying a beautifully displ dish of oysters. His phone is BUZZING. He ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman has now blended into the mingling guests. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We see ARTHUR TAUB (45), the nuclear submarine. He is greeting his guests. Arthur notices Norman from the corner of his eye. Norman casually picks up a hors d'oeuvre from a passing waiter, while he nods his head toward Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman has walked up to the second level of the house. He examines the hors d'oeuvre in his hand - it looks like stuffed fig with an unidentified nut topping - Norman sme it. knowing he can’t eat it, he places it on a mantel behind decorative statue. Then he peeks through the large doors leading into the fo dining room. From Norman’s POV we see a long, fancy dinne table with approximately 20 settings. Next to each settin there is a name card. Norman walks in, going over the name cards until he locat the card that says MICAH ESHEL. It is a proud moment for to have literally secured (by proxy) a seat at the table. He pulls out his phone and dials again. “Eshel private ce He takes a deep, troubled breath as he realizes that Eshe not picking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests are now entering the dining area, finding thei seats around the table. Norman is already sitting comfortably by the table, on th seat marked for Micha Eshel. He smiles nonchalantly at the guests as they take their s around him. Arthur, who is talking to a few people on the other side the room, notices Norman sitting by the table. He whispers something into the ear of A WOMAN standing ne to him. She is Arthur's assistant. The smiling assistant approaches Norman. She leans down s that she is very close to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR'S ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: (very quietly) Mr. Taub would like to speak with you. Do you mind joining me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Of course. Thank you (to the couple sitting next to him) Excuse me... Norman and Arthur’s (smiling) assistant step out and disappear into a corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assistant leaves Norman waiting in this indoor basket court which apparently serves as Arthur's kids own all purpose playroom. Norman looks around, taking in the extravagant setting. He has his business card ready in hi hand. Arthur enters.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Mr. Oppenheimer?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Norman. We met at the Stern auction. M onute is friendly with Lili. By t I can’t thank you enough for ‘the ast_minute invitation for Eshel.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Where is he? Mr. Eshel.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: He’s on his way. I just spoke to him. He apologizes. He was held wu in a meeting at the U.N., But he is on this way...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: You just spoke to him now?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. A few minutes ago. Arthur is evaluating Norman. He seems amused, rather than angry.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: How do you know Mr. Eshel?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I've been helping him out with some of his American alliances. There are some very interesting ideas he is trying to promote... For instance, I’m sure you’ve heard of the tax money Israel is withholding now... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 returning wit 27.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: He has this genius idea for a third party to buy those tax receivables...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) And, just so that I understand, Mr. Eshel asked you to ask me if he can come tonight?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I told him about some of the work you've been doing with the cancer research fund in Israel and other initiatives you support and he was very excited to meet you... yes.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: You realize that this is an intimate dinner for a group of people who get together for a very Specific purpose, right?... And t at this is my house. My private ome...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: It is a beautiful home...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: You can’t just walk in and sit at my table. I was happy to include Mr. Eshel, even though I found it a bit odd that he would invite himself to a dinner through someone I don’t actually know, But if he is not here, the invitation is not up for grabs. You understand that, right? are speaking, Norman notices Arthur’s assistant Norman’s COAT and HAT over her arm.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: He should be here any moment...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Well then why don’t you wait for him outside and when he arrives I promise you we will make him feel very comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: You want me to wait outside?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Okay « That’s fine. I’m sure he will ere any minute. Thank you, Arthur. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Arthur is not sure what to make of Norman. He gives him o last look before he turns around and leaves. Once alone with Norman, Arthur's assistant’s smile disappears. She opens a service door leading to the back yard. Norman takes his coat and hat, thanks the assistant with head gesture, then leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman, deflated, is sitting on a bench opposite the townhouse. He is emptying the last candy out of his box of Mike and pkes, chewing on them obsessively, and scratching his col one. From his POV, through the large windows of the townhouse, see Arthur and his guests enjoying their privileged dinne Norman rips apart the Gandy box to make sure it is really empty, then gets up and walks away into the dark park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an old Upper West Side building. Norman comes walking down the block. He stops by the synagogue and presses his face against the glass door. He tries the door. It is opened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a CHOIR and a CANTOR echoing in the foyer. Norman steps into the main sanctuary, following the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CANTOR and his CHOIR are rehearsing a cantorial piece i this modest in size, but beautiful old New York synagogue The cantor acknowledges Norman with a slight head-nod, as continues the rehearsal. Norman steps out and enters a small kitchenette off the m sanctuary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman, hungry, finds a box of Ritz crackers on the count and a bottle of ginger ale. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He takes a fist-full of crackers and pours himself a pape cup full of ginger ale. He opens the refrigerator and pul out a JAR OF PICKLED HERRING. Just as he is about to place a piece of herring on a crac he hears rapid footsteps descending down a staircase. Nor quickly returns the cracker box and the jar to where they were. RABBI BLUMENTHAL, a 50 year-old beardless rabbi, emerges the stairwell, noticing Norman on his way out. He has the energy of someone on speed.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: Norman Oppenheimer! If you came to hear my class, you’re a little late...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: If I had the time... If I only had the time.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: You’re busy. That’s good. Someone has to make sure the world out there is still spinning... What’s new? Who’s winning? Who’s losing? Tell me something exciting.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I just got back from a very special evening. Fascinating people... (casually) At Arthur Taub’s house.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: You were in Arthur Taub’s house?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I brought Micha Eshel with me. I should introduce you to him. You know who he is, right?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: Say the name again...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Micha Eshel. He’s in the Israeli parliament. Young. Charismatic. Sharp - Very sharp. I’m helping him out a bit... showing him the ropes. I’m going to help him raise some money. We sense Rabbi Blumenthal is skeptical of Norman’s name- dropping, but he plays along so not to offend him.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: Good for you. He is a lucky man to have you on his side. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I’m the lucky one. Believe me, this guy - he’s the real thing. He’s an incredible human being.

dialogues.speaker: __ RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: Maybe bring him to us as a guest lecturer. If you say he’s good...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Next time he is here. We’ll make an evening out of it...

dialogues.speaker: _, RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: Sounds like a plan, Norman. Rabbi Blumenthal looks at Norman. He doesn’t believe a wo e just heard, but going along with it is easier than Ben ronting Norman. RABBI BLUMENTHAL (CONT’D) I’m going to head home. You staying?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (referring to the cantor in the background) zt relaxes me. I’1l listen for a it. Rabbi Blumenthal nods his head and leaves Norman alone in kitchenette. Norman takes a handful of crackers before he exits--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman quietly sits down on one of the benches and listen THE CHOIR AND CANTOR REHEARSE. The entire wall in front of him is covered with MEMORIAL PLAQUES. Hundreds of names engraved in bronze sheets on t wall. Norman pulls out his phone and looks down at the screen, scrolling down his contact list, waiting, hoping, his pho will ring. But it doesn’t. He looks up. One name plaque in particular catches Norman attention. We close in on it: HENRY KAVISH INT. ESHEL’S HOTEL SUITE - NIGHT 39 WITH THE CANTORIAL HARMONY STILL UNDER THE SCENE. Eshel is alone in his hotel room. He is drunk after a who bottle of wine all to himself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He collapses onto his bed and sees the SHOEBOX from Lanvi He opens the box. Pulls out a SHOE. He stares at it with admiration. He notices Norman’s business card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman’s phone RINGS. He looks at the screen, his face lights up: “Eshel Privat Cell.” Norman had just stepped out of the s nagoque, but when he tries to reenter, doors are now er Before Norman answers the call, he walks around the build into a narrow service alley where there are decorative windows into the main sanctuary and rows of garbage cans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman finds a spot, takes a deep breath--

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Hello Sir. INT./EXT. ALLEY - SHARED WITH - ESHEL’S HOTEL SUITE 42

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men are now SUPERIMPOSED on the screen: Eshel, ly on his back, holding the shoe up in front of his face, No in the alley, by the garbage cans. The CHOIR CAN STILL BE HEARD. It annotates the scene.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Is it too late to call?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No. Not at all. I just got back from Arthur’s dinner.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I couldn't make it. It was a crazy day. I’m really sorry.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: That’s okay. No need to apologize. We'll find another opportunity. I told Arthur all about you.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I feel terrible. Do you forgive me? Norman pauses on this. As if it is the first time in his anyone asked him that question. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Please, don’t give it another thought.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah? You sure?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Positive.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I want you to know how much I appreciate what you did for me today. I really do. It was... nice.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I’m glad.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Me too. Thank you, Norman.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No, thank you. Eshel’s head drops back, he is about to pass out. NORMAN (CONT’D) Mr. Eshel?

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: How _do you say galgal_ anak in English? The big wheel in the amusement park. Like in London...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: A Ferris wheel?

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Yes. A Ferris wheel. Sometimes you are up and sometimes you are down. I just wanted to say that to you.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. I know what you mean..

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I've tasted it on my tongue. Being on top of everything. Once you taste it, you can’t settle for anything less. Do you know that, Norman? Do you understand what I am saying? Norman is confused by Eshel’s slurred speech, but he resp with his utmost sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I do too. I do too... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eshel passes out. The CHOIR FADES OUT.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Eshel? Norman stays on the line, listening to Eshel’s heavy breathing. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: It is my great honor to welcome the prime minister of the state of Israel-- Micha Eshel... A ROAR OF APPLAUSE AND ECSTATIC CHEERING, takes us into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a ballroom the size of a football field. THOUSANDS OF MEN AND WOMAN are on their feet, applauding cheering. We see the stage. It is the annual AIPAC convention in Washington. A single, official speaking podium is set in the center o the vast, somewhat futuristically designed stage. A MUSICAL INTRODUCTION (with pathos at the level of the S Wars theme) is playing on the PA, accompanying the entran of Micha Eshel, waving, smiling, overwhelmed by this IMPE welcoming.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you very much. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you Michael. Thank you. Thank you all... Thank you. Thank you... But the applause won’t stop. Eshel absorbs it in. Allowin the love to flow. Our camera closes in on his unavoidable smirk, then slowl moves down his body and stops on his - METALLIC BROWN SHO Way, way back, far from the stage, Norman Oppenheimer is the audience, appiaudin with the masses, his name tag dangling around his neck. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He is standing so far away from the stage, Eshel is too s for Norman to see his face. So Norman has his head directed at one of the large scree in the ballroom, projecting Eshel’s exuberant face. Norman is in tears. Tears of genuine excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long line of MEN and WOMEN has formed around a highly guarded reception area where Eshel and other VIPs are sha ands and greeting each other. Norman is looking at Eshel from a distance. From his POV see Duby, Eshel’s lawyer who is now his chief of staff. And HANNA (38) curly hair, nice smile and energetic eyes. They are standing behind Eshel with cell phones in their hands, whispering to each other and occasionally into Esh ear, monitoring the people who get to approach the new pr minister. Philip Cohen approaches Norman. He has a plate of PECAN P WITH IPPED CREAM in his hand. Together they continue to look at Eshel from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: For once I bet on the right horse. What were the odds? It is a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Have you spoken to him yet? I mean since he won?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: We‘ve been exchanging messages. It’s not that simple to reach him anymore. He’s got a lot on his plate.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: And... from now on, I mean, how does it work? Are you friends? How close are you? Do you get to visit him in his office? When he comes to the States does he invite you to have breakfast with him at Blair House?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: To tell you the truth, I don’t know. From my side, I "want him to know that I’m here for him if he needs me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Philip looks at Norman, trying to evaluate how sincere he Norman appears to be not only sincere - but truly moved b the magnitude of this event.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Can you introduce me to him? Norman looks at the long line of people waiting for their turn with Eshel.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Of course! But let’s wait for the right moment. I don’t want to push myself on him.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: If you don’t go up to him, he won’t know you're here. Norman is hesitant. PHILIP (CONT’ D) Look at him. He is sealed off, very few people have access to him’ now that he is King. For all you_ know he may never return your calls, or worse - he may never even receive your messages.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Micha is a friend.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Micha? There is no more Micha. There is prime minister Eshel, and he has millions of friends. You need to get on that line. Norman knows Philip is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With AT LEAST TWENTY PEOPLE ahead of them, Norman and Phi are standing on line to meet Eshel. From Norman’s POV we hear bits and pieces of the conversa around Eshel and see visual fragments of these very quick awkward encounters. We jump cut from one encounter to the next, emphasizing t repetitiveness. One of the people introduced is--

As Norman and Philip move up in line, we also get a sense how this works: Hanna spots the person next in line, toge with another AIDE she verifies their identity, then she whispers the info into Duby’s ear. Hanna is the friendly one. Duby is protective and suspici We close in on Norman. He is only 4 or 5 people away from meeting Eshel and he is suddenly very nervous about what might happen.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Pastor Kermit Little, founder of Christians Assembly for Israel.

She looks down at her lists. Turns a few pages. Nothing. Duby’s suspicious, intimidating eyes also fall on Norman a brief second. Norman fixes his NAME TAG so that it is in clear view. Philip looks over at Norman. Norman is doing his best to project ease. But Philip senses his distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Fine. I might be reacting to something in the room. But I’m okay... The aide standing next to Hanna is going through her list well, finally finding what she was looking for. Norman sees her whisper something into Hanna’s ear, who whispers something into Duby’s ear, who looks up directly Norman. On the sound-track - background ambiance disappears. Norman is as helpless and pale as a condemned man about t hear his verdict. Then he hears-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Norman Oppenheimer, from New York... Eshel turns to face Norman. A beat. There is definite favorable recognition. Eshel’s face bre into a huge and warm smile. Sound-track back to normal.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Norman!! My friend! Where have you been? I’ve been trying to reach you. Norman finally can breathe again, allowing Eshel to pull in for a warm and meaningful embrace. Secret service agents, aides, photographers, all seem to close in on Norman, but not in a threatening way - they a all smiling at him. Including Jo Wilf, who is watching Norman with a curious on his face. All but Duby - who is not smiling and still seems very suspicious of Norman.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Duby and Hanna You know Norman, right? They all shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Naomi. Come meet Norman Oppenheimer. Norman, this is my wife Naomi. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: He is?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course. Look around you. Look around... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED

dialogues.speaker: VIBRANT, LOUD, PRESSING SOCIAL ENCOUNTERS.

We need to understand how this incredible force unites around the issues that are important for the Jewish people... and the world! Duby can relax. Another empty, meaningless promise. But it is enough to impress Philip. And confuse Norman. EDASH! Their picture is taken against the backdrop of the ags. The next people in line are ushered up to Eshel, and Norm is prepared to move aside, but Eshel won’t let go of Norm arm.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Congressman. Mrs. Love. Philip leans in, reminding Norman of his presence. NORMAN (CONT’D) This is my nephew, Philip Cohen, I think he is the youngest partner at Frankle, Zell, Gould and Rudoff in New York. Right?

dialogues.text: Very nice to meet you. One of the youngest...

dialogues.text: (pulling him in closer) I’m SOrry 1 T didn’t introduce you. ilip, meet prime minister Eshel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Philip. Duby, why do I know that firm? PHILIP ESHEL (CONT' Dy We represented Toby Sure, Toby... I know Toby. Tabatchnik, I think he is..

dialogues.text: Toby is married to a Solomon. Beth. She is Charlie Solomon's daughter...

AS THIS CONVERSATION CONTINUES-- Our camera gradually mov up and away from the commotion around Eshel. Norman is in center of it, shaking hands, laughing, talking, accepting business cards. From a high angle, it all appears like a busy BEEHIVE. Hundreds of people, buzzing around the room, maneuvering toward the center. The camera stops high above the room with this intricate, dynamic, human pattern filling our entire frame, illustra the elaborate network that is being formed in front of ou eyes... --FREEZE!

dialogues.speaker: WITHIN THE FREEZE
dialogues.text: On Norman: looking around him - he sees a forest of human encounters frozen in time. Just as great composers create perfect harmonies in their mind, as world-class chess players can plan 50 moves ahea so Norman's genius comes into play in this room, at this moment. He sees how it all connects! Norman examines the different frozen interactions. --He sees Arthur (nuclear submarine) Taub. He examines hi cocky face without_any spite or resentment, only a satisf smile that says - I have arrived! He also sees Arthur’s (still smiling) assistant. --Then he looks over at BILL KAVISH, standing next to JO WILE. Bill has a strained smile and drops of sweat on his orehea (CONTINUED)

46 --Then Norman sees Rabbi Blumenthal trying to push his wa into a cluster of people, but seems to be bloc aggressive socialites. ed out by more --And Philip, right behind Norman, next to Eshel, in his element, mid-conversation, radiant with charisma. Norman pulls out of his pocket his BUSINESS CARDS HOLDER. He extracts one and feels it with his fingers like one fe quality silk.

dialogues.text: Jo, I want you to meet a relative of mine, Norman Oppenheimer. Norman, this is Jo Wilf. Norman is close with Eshel...

dialogues.text: It wasn’t till my_late teens that_ god personally touched me. It was after the war in 67. Tens of thousands were connecting that historic event to a tremendous release of the spirit. Most of them had a supernatural experience. When the lord touched me. When He manifested himself to me...

dialogues.text: How come I don’t know you? I know every Oppenheimer in the world...

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Norman. (handing over his card) We‘re the only organization that is doing what James, the lord’s brother, said to do in Acts 15. We’re restorin David's fallen tabernacte 41. 48

dialogues.speaker: AMOS CHERTOFF
dialogues.text: (Southern accent) Amos Chertoff. Messianic Jewish Alliance of America. Very nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: JO WILF
dialogues.text: How close is_ close? Close close? Or “close”?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: (in confidence) When can we talk? Do you have time next week? We’re losing our building, that’s what’s oing on. See what you can o. I’1l see you at the board meeting. Yes? Get moving, Norman. Get moving. We're depending on you...

dialogues.speaker: DICK WEAVER
dialogues.text: There are a lot of ideas out there that are not biblical, so keeping it sound and grounded in good doctrine is hard. That is one of the reasons we do what we do at MIA. Meet sister Agnes. Agnes, this is Norman, a very ose friend of prime minister Eshel.

dialogues.text: That’s pretty close. Good to know. Eshel, he is still a mystery to me... Tell me something about him... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIOR
dialogues.text: Wait, do you know Bruce Parish?

dialogues.speaker: GIL
dialogues.text: (Israeli_accent) 42. 48

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE PARISH
dialogues.text: Look, for us at the NUF it is pretty simple and straightforward. The rule of law. Free and fair elections. Independent judiciary. Independent control of the military. Gay rights... Israel Inc. It is actually a sales agency for Israel. The goal is to encourage positive views of Israel. We even aim further. We get people on a plane, get them to Israel. Introduce them to the most inspiring people in the world. Israel aS a must see experience. Have you met Barbara Klein? Startup State... Let me introduce you...

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA KLEIN
dialogues.text: I work with Peter Black at a hedge fund called Stanely.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’ve never seen two people come out of a smorgasbord with the same plate... But we all_can still sit at the same table, can’t we?

dialogues.speaker: GIL
dialogues.text: It’s all about what is in it for YOU. We give you what you want and we get what we need. By not including politics or religion in our agenda simply because it doesn’t sell.

dialogues.speaker: AMOS CHERTOFF
dialogues.text: We cast our demons out of everything alive or dead. Under the power of God descending like that- (raking a sound of ierce wind) -you cannot remain still... It literally blew me out the door.

dialogues.speaker: PETER BLACK
dialogues.text: Our mission is to make sure New York doesn’t turn into New Havana..

dialogues.text: Norman, introduce me to Ariel De La Pelgula. I saw you talking to him. Next time the Pope is in New York, there is no reason the only tabbi he meets is Alan Schweitzer!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: My brothers and sisters in e African American group, the Latino group the Chinese group, the inilippino group. We work together to share the gospel with the Jewish people. Do you know Fred Stokes? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: All of your family goes to hell, but you get to be saved?! That's not good news! We have to find a way to talk to_the Jewish man and woman. Deliver the good news!

dialogues.text: (pulling Bill Kavish into the frame) Look, there might be something for us to talk about. Call my office. Bill, make sure we get in touch with Mr. Oppenheimer.

dialogues.text: ..-attract emerging nations, business leaders, academics, NGOs, entrepreneurs and teach the tools, the special sauce, the magic dust that Israel has to offer in respect to innovation. The brand is creativity.

dialogues.text: (looking at the card, then into Norman’s eyes) This is a cell phone. Do you have an office? An address? (pulling Norman aside) My son, Davidy, he wants to go to Harvard Business School, he doesn’t have the grades, but he has a good instincts, believe me, like his mother. Do you know somebody who can help him with his ,application? I don’t want any specia treatment... just a few tips. To understand what they are looking for.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: His grades are very good. But he missed some of his exams because he had to go to miluim, you know what miluim is? Army service. What can you do? We live in a tough neighborhood... but he is an excellent student.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Please, don’t speak to anyone on behalf of the prime minister. If he asks you for something, it is important that you speak to me or with Hanna first. Okay? (handing over her card) Feel free to call me. That’s what I’m here for. Any time. Don’t worry, all his calls so don’t use any of t ge though me, e old numbers. I’m so happy to finally meet you in person... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE PARISH
dialogues.text: (candidly) If the goal is achieved by speaking privately, we'll speak privately. Not everything has to be public. Is there not a certain humility or restraint the Jewish Leaders should exercise when real lives hang in the balance?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: Without a building, without those four walls a floor and a ceiling, we’re like an old wine in a broken bottle. Something physical has to hold us together...

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA KLEIN
dialogues.text: We're working on a documentary that is fully funded. But only so many people see documentaries. So we are also cooking up a feature film. Apparently there hasn't been a feature film that’s been seductive about Israel since Exodus, so we're working on a romantic comedy set in Israel...

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: That Rabbi you spoke with, Blumenthal, is he friendly? Do you think he can help me with Nicole’s conversion?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA KLEIN

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: Here, take my card... Call me! Norman takes it_all in. He is drunk, but not from alcohol He has never felt this safe, or at home, in his life. The last image in this series of FLASHES from Norman’s PO is a shot of Eshel being escorted out of the room by a de herd of aides and security. Eshel turns his head and gives Norman one last look. There is longing in Norman’s eyes as he watches Eshel disappear.

dialogues.text: Norman’s cab stops my the main entrance. Norman gets out the cab and enters the station.  51 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALEXANDRA (ALEX) GREEN (30s) is entering the train car st at the platform of Union Station. She takes off her coat she finds a seat by the aisle. There is an AIPAC NAME TAG still hanging around her neck under her coat. Once she sits down, we notice Norman entering the car . H sees her name tag and smiles at her, sitting across the a from her.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Norman Oppenheimer. Nice to meet you. (reading off her name tag) Alex Green.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you too. I guess we can take these off now. They both remove their name tags. Alex pulls out her iPad but before she can turn it on--

dialogues.text: What brings you to AIPAL?

dialogues.text: I represent one of the organizations.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX

dialogues.speaker: _. NORMAN

dialogues.text: Where are you from? Where were you born? How did you end up here?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX

dialogues.text: Really? Geneva! Then you must know a close friend of mine... Leo Reiss. Alex shakes her head, no, she does not know him.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No? Very famous family, a big supporter of the Israel museum. His wife Sophia... No? Alex shakes her head. Norman senses her coldness, so he l go. As passengers continue to enter the train, walking throug the isle between them-- NORMAN (CONT’D) Wait... Green... Any connection to Julian Green? From Basel... Alex shakes her head again. The last PASSENGER has entered the car. He stops ri ht between them and indicates to Alex that he would e the seat next to her. Alex gets up to allow him to get in.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (moving over in his seat) You are welcome to sit here... If you're busy, I won’t bother you. Don’t worry... Alex looks up at the seat situation in the car. The last travelers are finding their seats, filling up most of the car. She doesn’t really have a civil way to refuse, so sh collects her stuff and sits next to Norman.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Thank you. As she turns on her iPad--

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: What do you do in the consulate?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I've had dinner with your boss a few times. Yuval. The consul general. Interesting fellow... You can send him my regards. Alex nods her head with a blank smile. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Welcome aboard Amtrak Acela express. For your safety please take a moment to review the safet instructions card in the seat-bac in front of you... THE TRAIN BEGINS TO MOVE. If you are seated in the quiet car, pease refrain from using cell phones and please speak in subdued tones. Thank you for choosing Amtrak.
