dialogues.text: _ (smilin . 4 This isn’t the quiet car, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eshel, Duby, Hanna, Naomi and other AIDES AND STAFF toget with the regular GROUP OF SECRET SERVICE MEN, enter one o the large drawing rooms, still swarming with JOURNALISTS, EMBASSY STAFF AND OTHER GUESTS. The official/ceremonial part of the day is over and Eshel in a playful, jet-lagged mood.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Everybody! Go home. Go to sleep! Leave me alone! The historical bond between the United States and Israel has never been stronger, you can all relax. At least tilt tomorrow morning. Right Duby?

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: {smiling The “specia relationship” is intact!

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: That's right. The “special, relationship”. And... Eshel lifts his hand as if he is conducting a choir.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, DUBY AND EVERYBODY ELSE
dialogues.text: The “unwavering ‘commitment to Israel's security...”

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Yafe. The unwavering commitment. Now, please, leave me alone... Get some sleep. If I have to shake one more hand tonight, my fingers will fall off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eshel allows himself to fall into one of the sofas in the room. He loosens his tie and kicks off his SHOES. With Hanna’s encouragement, most of the people exit the r But there is one tall, slim MAN in his 60s waiting patien in the corner of the room who is not leaving. His name is BRUCE SCHWARTZ.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: (to Eshel) One more hand to shake, I’m afraid. You've met Bruce Schwartz before, haven't you? Special Middle East Coordinator Bruce comes over and sits in one of the chairs opposite Eshel.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Just over the phone. Good to finally meet in person, rime minister. We don’t have to shake hands...

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: That is very considerate of you. They shake hands anyway.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're not going to make me put on my shoes, are you?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: No. This is as informal as could be.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Good. The formal me needs a rest...

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Bruce would like to go over some points before tomorrow’s meeting with the president. Bruce leans in. Duby and Hanna lean in too, to Bruce’s surprise.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: It is less about your meeting with the president and more about the statements you will deliver elsewhere in town. As somebody who occupies a fairly tough job himself the president is always ympathetic to foreign leaders dea ing with complicated internal politics... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Let me stop you. Excuse me. Ani lo tzarich et hahartzaah hazot. Duby, on instinct, is about to interfere, but Eshel signa him to remain out of it.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please tell the president that I am here to say ‘yes’ to peace. I’m sorry - “state of peace” as we agreed to call it. I fully accept his vision. I understand it and I believe in it. No internal politics will change my commitment to the Wye document. Duby, Hanna and Bruce are all surprised by how firm Eshel sounds. Surprised and relieved. Eshel gets up to grab a handful of CHOCOLATE COVERED NUTS of a bowl on one of the tables --

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This evening I had to... Duby, how do you say mas sefataim?

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: To pay lip service.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I had to pay lip service to a few organizations on a few minor issues, but I promise you it has no substance. BRUCE | ; I’m sure the president will...

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: (cutting Bruce off, sitting across from him) You know what I’ve found out in the last couple of weeks since I was elected? It is very strange, because it is the opposite of what I thought I would feel. Maybe the president can identify with me... For the first time in my professional life, I have no political worries. This is true. I don’t care if I’m reelected. Somehow God put me in this job. It is not that I didn’t work very hard to get here, I did, but hundreds of other potential leaders worked and campaigned just as hard as I did, and for some reason I’m the one sitting in this chair today. The top spot. I’ve reached the top of the ladder. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eshel picks up a SMALL FLAG that was placed on the table, gets up for more chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why me? And not someone else? Who knows. Believe me, I’m as surprised as everyone else. But this is the interesting thing - instead of feeling the burden of that great responsibility, I’m feeling... Duby, iech omrim goral?

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Fate.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I feel... Fate, which weighs nothing at all. If God put me here, he must have had a good reason. I’m not free to run away from this job, but to be honest - no single human being can really claim to be big enough for this job either. Hanna and Duby exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: (to Bruce) I would be nappy to go over our itinerary with you so that we can discuss the sensitivities of each group...

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: (to Bruce, cutting Duby) What is it that really worries the president? Tell me. I want to know. What doesn’t he want me to say?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Well, you have been saying different things in different forums. I think we are trying to get a better understanding of the singular message you wish to deliver.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: You were there tonight, right? Hanna » how many completely opposing organization 1 leaders came up to me said - we're behind yous You have our support to stan our ground. How many? 50? 100? Yeach with a completely different agenda. There is no such thing as a felis yo message. And anyone who tel you he has a singular message is probably teaching at a university or writing a blog. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean it that way, I’m sorry if...

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: (cutting Bruce) I‘1l tell you what my singular message is. I’m going to end this conflict. How? I’m going to say ‘yes’ to compromise, to EVERYBODY! Because the opposite of compromise is not idealism. The opposite of compromise is not integrity. The opposite of compromise is fanaticism and death. LIFE is compromise. I not only believe in that. That is who I am. That is why I'm here, in this position, If it works, I will go down in history as the leader who ended this epic conflict. If I’m wrong, and BY compromise leads to another bloody war - I will blame God for giving me a role I was incapable o: performing. Eshel’s confused monologue, (only a notch below Dr. Strangelove level) is a result of extreme fatigue and the high level of adrenaline his body has been releasing all night. But now he is done. Eshel pops the last chocolate covered nut into his mouth, picks up his SHOES and walks ou Bruce, Duby and Hanna have gone from pleasant surprise in beginning of his monologue, to complete shock at the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to Norman and Alex. The train is in motion. The ligh have been dimmed.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: So can I ask you, what kind of stuff do you deal with?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (covering her iPad) There is what’s called a mutual legal assistance treaty between Israel and the United States. We have our hands full...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I can imagine. Like what kind of things? Commerce agreements?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, that is a different department. We are an arm of the Tsracli justice ministry in the United States. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We coordinate criminal investigations, judicial procedure, extradition.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: So if an Israeli criminal flees to America, you're in charge of bringing him back?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: We would be involved in that, yes.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Or if an American criminal tries to hide out in Israel...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes, that too.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Wow. So do you have any interesting stories for me? Like with all those Russian oligarchs who are wanted all_over the world and ask for asylum in Israel. Tell me how that works from the inside... Alex shakes her head. Her lips are sealed.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Do you know Carol Raskin? If I’m not mistaken, she wrote some of these international treaties. She’s a good friend of mine. Do you know Carol?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Not personally, no, but I know who she is...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I'd be happy to introduce you...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That’s not necessary. I wouldn’t want to bother her. But thank you. She is a solid brick wall, leaving Norman no entrance poi Alex looks at her watch. Then at Norman, who has no readi material, and doesn’t seem like he plans on sleeping. She pulls out a pair of EARPHONES from her bag. As she inserts one into her ear - Norman catches a quick glimpse a SIMPLE GOLD WEDDING BAND on Alex's finger.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Family? Kids? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She pulls out the earphone.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. What?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Do you have a family? Kids?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: A partner.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: You’re a lesbian?? Alex laughs. Finally.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes. I am.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Good for you. That’s terrific.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I like it when people know what they want. It’s a good thing. To be focused. You know, I have a close friend, a fascinating man named rabbi, professor Nathaniel Lewis, he teaches at JTS. He has a daughter who started a_ Jewish lesbian organization. Abigail Lewis. Do you know her? Alex shakes her head. NORMAN (CONT’D) You should meet her. You’1l love her. I can get you two together...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That is the third time in five minutes that you offered to introduce me to someone. Why are you trying to_get me to meet people? Do I 180k lonely? Norman looks at her for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Why do you feel that_I need these roductions? Have I given you that impression? That I’m looking for connections? Norman shakes his head. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry - I didn’t mean to offend you. zr just thought it made sense. And maybe it is good for Abigail too, to meet someone at the Israeli consulate. But maybe I’m wrong... He turns away to face the window.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean that as criticism. I apologize if it came out that way. NORMAN ; Then what are you saying? I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Never mind. I appreciate you trying to help connect me, it is just that I don’t need connections right now.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: So what do you need?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What do I need??

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m sitting next to you on the train, we were both at the convention together, how can I help you? I'm offering my assistance. I’m a good person to know. Take advantage of that. What do you need? I’1l help you get it. Alex sincerely thinks this over for a moment, but comes u with --

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I don’t need anything.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Impossible. Everybody needs something. Even tough lesbian lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I need many things, but not necessarily things you can help wit!

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Try me.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I need the satisfaction of knowing that I'm doing good in the world. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (scratching his ear) That’s a big one. They both smile.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your parents - they’re proud of you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I think so. I hope so...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: They should be. Alex sees that Norman means it and accepts his complement

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What about you? Family? Kids?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: A daughter just finished graduate school. Her mother died when she was three.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Sorry to hear that. You raised your daughter alone?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I did my best, yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That must have been difficult.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: You_know what_they say - small children, small problems...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: And why were you at the convention? I noticed you were speaking with the prime minister. You know him well? Norman hesitates for a brief moment before he responds. T

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. I do. Micah is a close friend.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: How did you meet him?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I bought him a pair of shoes.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You bought him a pair of shoes? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (in a sweet folkie melody) You never know... You never know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know. Miraculously, Alex is now completely captivated by Norman

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What do you mean you bought him a pair of shoes?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: You never know. A pair of shoes. The most expensive shoes in all of New York, but the best investment I made in my life. Norman pauses. From here on the scene is shot in extreme close-ups, accentuating every tiny, careful, move they ma like bomb disposal experts picking a path through a minefield.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: May I ask what you do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I’m a businessman.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What sort of business?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Consulting. Mostly.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You work in a consulting firm?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Firm? No. It is basically only me these days.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Who do you consult?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Businesses. Organizations. Individuals. It varies. Sometimes I consult other consultants. Norman smiles. So does Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Do you have a specific area of expertise? Can you explain to me how your business works? If it is not too complicated... I’m curious. Norman examines her face. Maybe there is something she “needs” after all.  54 55 56 57 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide shot of our train zooming by in the night, en rout Manhattan. OVER VARIOUS IMAGES OF THE TRAIN IN MOVEMENT: Norman’s an Alex's faces are SUPERIMPOSED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don’t hear their dialogue, but we SEE a heightened ver of their conversation. --Norman is explaining something to Alex. At first subtly with a modesty in his facial expressions, then with more more enthusiasm. --Alex is nodding her head, smiling, raising her eyebrows with surprise. --Norman drawing a diagram on a piece of paper with NAMES NUMBERS and ARROWS connecting the different names, as he in the first scene with Philip. For this part, Alex has p on her READING GLASSES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The superimposed faces fade out, dgaving us with an image the train entering the final tunnel leading into Penn Station, stopping only an inch from the BUFFER STOP at th end of the track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman and Alex exit the train onto the platform. We sens the three hour ride has created a bond between them. Norman takes a BUSINESS CARD out of his wallet and hands to Alex. It is his last.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I know you don’t need anything, and I’m not offering anything, I definitely won’t introduce you to anyone. But, take this card, please... take it. You never know. You never know... Alex accepts Norman’s business card.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (looking at the card) Thank you, Norman. Our ride together was very interesting.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: That’s it?? Come here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He pulls her in for a HUG. It makes Alex laugh. She doesn reciprocate, but she doesn’t resist him either.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take care, Alex. Good luck. She smiles and takes off toward one of the escalators. As she disappears up the escalator, she waves his busines card, indicating that she will be in touch. Norman, alone on the platform, waves back to her, satisfi CUT TO ALEX'S FACE: Once out of Norman’s sight, her smile disappears. She places Norman’s card in her purse and tak deep, troubled breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is sitting by a table alone in the only shop that is open at this hour. She is looking at her YELLOW LEGAL PAD which Norman scribbled the messy diagram with names and arrows, specifying next to each name what he or she “NEED or “CAN GIVE”. Alex is copying down the names to a new sheet of paper. Then she looks up. From her POV we see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other side of the station, entering the closed-off waiting area, Norman is wandering through the empty seats finally sitting down. He takes off his shoes. He pulls ou his pocket a box of MIKE AND IKES, chewing on them 3 at a time. Alex is watching him from a distance. She picks up his business card and decides to dial his number. We see Norman look at his phone and answer the call.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Hello...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Hi. It’s Alex. From the train... Just now.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Alex! I’m so glad you called. I’m just getting into a cab. Should I pick you up? Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I’m still at Penn Station. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We see Norman look around, wondering if he is caught. He can’t see Alex through the glass barriers and across the hall, but Alex is not hiding from him. It feels as if she actually wants him to see her.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: On the street?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No. I’m still inside. Norman is silent for a second.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is everything okay, Norman?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Everything is perfect. Couldn’t be better. This whole evening... it’s like I’m floating on a cloud. What about you - are you okay? Why did you call? Alex looks down at the diagram on her pad. Then--

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I realized just now that I didn’t give you my number and I wanted you to have it. You never know... FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking down from the third floor of a creaky stairwell in Rabbi Blumenthal’s synagogue. WE HEAR HEAVY FOOTSTEPS CLIMBING UP THE STEPS. A PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: (out-of-breath, trying to whisper Philip, I’m in a meeting, can I call you back in about twenty minutes? --Yes. I’1l call you. Bye - weeny ening | is perfect. -- No. Not ye I need to find the right moment. Trust me, okay? -- Please don’t say that. I asked you to trust me. Give me a few more minutes. Bye. --Yes. Bye. Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman gradually ascends, step after heavy step, revealin himself to us. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He doesn’t look like everything is perfect. He is fatigue from the walk-up, carrying his coat, scarf, gloves, hat, umbrella and PHONE in his hands. Norman looks at his phone for a moment, deliberating whet or not to make a call. Finally, he decides to press CALL. INT. HANNA’S OFFICE - EVENING - ISRAEL 62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna is by her desk in the prime minister’s office in Jerusalem. Her phone is RINGING, but she is letting it ri There is a TREMENDOUS BOUQUET OF ROSES on her desk. Hanna looks tired and upset, holding her head, looking do at_a CARD. We close in on the card. It reads: I’M SO SORR PLEASE, PLEASE FORGIVE ME. NORMAN OPPENHEIMER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With dilated nostrils, Norman inhales and exhales twice before he gives up and hangs up. Norman closes his eyes, as if to restart his mood. When he opens his eyes, he has resolved himself for whate lies ahead. He exits the frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a medium size hall on the third floor of the synagogue. A group of 9 MEN and 3 WOMEN are convened around a table the center of this elegant but outdated room, conducting we will soon find out is a Synagogue board meeting. Norma appears at the entrance to this hall.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: Look who showed up... Our savior has finally arrived.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late. Norman walks in and sees that the table is scattered with little paper plates with different NUTS- almonds, walnuts pistachios and peanuts. NORMAN (CONT’D) (moving a plate of nuts) But that’s no reason to kill me. Can you get rid of the nuts please?  65 66 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nuts are gone. While we focus on Norman’s face, his breathing, his eyes moving around the room as he sits by this table, we hear Rabbi Blumenthal -

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: The situation is very simple. The National Council has decided to sell the building. They are willing to try their best to keep our lease as part of whatever agreement they sign with the new owners, but as we all understand, they can’t guarantee anything. TO be practica we need to raise ap) roximately fourteen million dollars, to save us from the wrecking ball and insure our future ere... We see Rabbi Blumenthal’s lips move, but we no longer hea him. Instead we focus on Norman's agitated face. This takes us into the following FRENETIC, FAST MOVING sequence recapping the events that lead tO this board meeting. INT. JO WILF’S OFFICE - SHARED WITH - INT. STAPLES STORE

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: On one side of the frame we see JO WILF, in his GRAND MID OFFICE. On the other side of the frame we see NORMAN in a STAPLES STORE, speaking on his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: JO WILF
dialogues.text: Norman, Philip tells me you can help me.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: You will have my best effort, yes.

dialogues.speaker: JO WILF
dialogues.text: Here, talk to Bill. Jo puts the call on SPEAKER - Bill Kavish steps up to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Norman, this is Bill. Norman?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Is Jo still there? Can he hear me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We see Jo signal to Bill to say no.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Jo had to_ step out. Let me tell you what we need. You with me?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (disappointed he has to deal with Bill) I’m all yours. Go ahead...

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: We have a colleague who could use a friendly introduction at the State Department...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: The state department?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Yes. You do that for us, open the door for him at the state department, get him in a room with Douglas Gordon - that thing Philip discussed with Jo - we’ll see what we can do. Jo Wilf looks over at the GROUP OF PEOPLE in his office w an expression that says - “it’s worth a try”. Norman passes a PEN TESTING PAD. He writes down- DOUGLAS GORDON, and takes the page with him. Then - Jo Wilf’s side of the frame is replaced with the interior of a BULLET PROOF LIMOUSINE in Israel.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT
dialogues.text: Hanna and Duby are in the back seat of a limo that is par Eshel’s motorcade passing through the streets of Jerusale Norman is still in the Staples store, looking over a vari of ENVELOPES on display.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Hanna, please, Just give me a minute with him on the phone. One minute. Less than a minute. This is something he wants to hear... Hanna looks at Duby who is shaking his head decisively - Absolutely not.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry, Norman. The prime minister is not available to speak right now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Then can I speak with Duby? Put Duby on the phone? (whisperin It has to do with a special request the prime minister asked me to look in to. Hanna looks at Duby - Duby is shaking his head - no!

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I'm afraid Duby is also unavailable. I’m sorry Norman. These are busy days for us. Unfortunately I can’t be more specific, but I’m sure you understand. Norman is visibly distressed by this. By now he has walke over to the OFFICE FURNITURE SECTION. He sits down on one the office chairs behind one of the desks on display, as this were his natural work area.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I understand. Of course. Alright. Please let the prime minister know that I have an answer for him and if he has a free moment, at any hour, day or night, it would be great if we can have a very, very short phone conversation about a certain individual on the board of the dean's advisers at Harvard business school.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: (checking with Duby...) I will, Norman. Thanks for calling. Duby is signaling with his hand to ask who the “certain individual” is.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you tell me who this person is?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: -- I’11 tell the prime minister ali about him when we speak. Duby smiles, shaking his head. He knows how Norman functi

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Okay, Norman. Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No — thank you, Hanna! Go back to doing your important work. I’m sorry for interrupting... You’re doing a great job and I know the prime minister appreciates it... Just don’t forget me Hanna, okay? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But Hanna has already hung up.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: (to Duby, in Hebrew) What do I do with him? That’s the fifth time I’ve blown him off.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Don’t say it as if you’ ve done something wrong. That’s your job. Keeping the Normans away.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Do you know what the prime minister wanted from him? Isn’t David applying to Harvard?

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: I don’t care. Norman does not get passed you. No matter what he says. If he becomes obsessive, you can take a call from him once every few days so that he doesn't get paranoid, and to keep the connection alive, but never, never put him through. Understood? Never. Hanna accepts this, but she doesn’t like it.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about Norman. Gettin you on the phone is enough for him. More than enough. In his head, he just had a conversion with the prime minister of Israel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is by the cashier, paying for a package of ENVELOP and a CARTRIDGE OF BLACK PRINTER INK. He is paying with a crumpled single dollar bills and a handful of quarters, d and nickels. Right before he checks out, he places a box MIKE AND IKES on the counter as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is dialing a new number. R. Blumenthal has a YOUNG COUPLE sitting in his office. H apologizes to them for having to take the call.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Rabbi! It’s Norman. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: Why don’t you answer your phone? I’ve been calling all morning.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I'm answering now. Do you want to hear what I have to say?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: You spoke to him?? What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t have a final answer yet, but it looks good. I’1l be at the board meeting with all the details but let’s just say - get ready for a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: What kind of surprise are we talking about? How many zeros does this surprise have? Can you tell me that at least?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (hailing a taxi) If I tell you, where’s the surprise? It’s a considerable surprise. Believe me. I gotta go, Rabbi. I’1l see you tomorrow... Blumenthal’s study apparently also serves as a CLEANING SUPPLIES storage place. The Rabbi picks up a WINDOW CLEAN SPRAY because he needs to wrap his fist round something.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI. BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: Norman, you realize how important this is, right? They are going to kick us out of here... You need to give us a firm answer. No games... Norman!?-- Norman! ! Norman has hung up. Rabbi Blumenthal faces the sweet couple waiting for him, doing his best to erase the anxiety on his face. He is then replaced with Jo Wilf and his team in Wilf’s office. And Norman is now sitting in a bus-stop. INT./EXT. BUS-STOP - SHARED WITH - INT. WILF’S OFFICE - D Norman has the box of MIKE AND IKEs on the bench next to He is eating 3 at a time.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I have a call with Eshel this evening, but I brought it up with his main man, Duby. I think it will be okay. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was very practical about it, said he would take care of it, he just needs the exact information. Can_you send me an e-mail with your colleague's name? Jo Wilf shakes his head toward Bill Kavish.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: No e-mails, Norman. His name is Matthias Kone, he is an official in the treasury department in_the Ivory Coast. Eshel’s office will need to reach out to him. We're not involved. It has to come from them. Maybe he can join their delegation in Davos... On Norman's face: The Ivory Coast - that doesn’t sound go to him. Jo Wilf’s office is replaced with Hanna and Duby now part the prime minister’s entourage at an HONORARY DOCTORATE CEREMONY in an unidentified University.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We enter during a musical interlude. A VERDI ARIA is bein performed on stage. On Hanna, off stage, surrounded by security guards: her c phone is blinking. Her screen reads - “Norman”. She shows to Duby. Duby smiles, signals with his fist that she need be firm.

dialogues.speaker: OPERA SINGER
dialogues.text: Tra la la la la la laaaaa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman hangs up. He rubs his eyes. Shit! (He either says thinks to himself) as he empties the box of MIKE AND IKEs into his palm. He dials a new number. INT./EXT. PHILIP COHEN’S OFFICE - SHARED WITH - EXT. FIFT

dialogues.speaker: AVE.
dialogues.text: Philip is on the phone with Norman who is exiting an offi building. It is noisy outside and Norman can hardly hear Philip.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: (losing his patience) ..-Anyone who applies to Harvard fills out the same standard form. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When they see his father’s name on the form it will immediately be brought to the dean’s attention that the son of the prime minister of Israel is applying for the business schoo You don’t need me for this.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Hold on a second. I can’t hear a word you are saying... Norman sees the entrance to Bergdorf Goodman across the street. He crosses over. INT. /EXT. BERGDORF GOODMAN - SHARED WITH - INT. PHILIP’S

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE
dialogues.text: First floor - jewelry and handbags. Norman is already on the escalator leading up to the seco floor.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (trying to keep his voice down, If it were that easy would I be asking you for neh He doesn’t have the grades, P ilip. He won’t get in without serious pressure and your personal intervention. Philip takes a deep breath. He doesn’t like this. Norman has arrived at the 2nd floor. Women’s shoes. It is beautiful and colorful and glamorous, buzzing with assertive women shopping for shoes. Norman finds a relatively quiet spot. Philip and Norman, each in their separate surroundings, a scratching their heads nervously. NORMAN (CONT’ D) Philip, it’s just a call.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: How is this connected to the rabbi again, Norman? Remind me... Why am I doing this?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: You are doing this because he is the prime minster of Israel and he is asking you for a favor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: No. He is asking YOU for a favor. Correct me if I’m wrong - you're getting the credit for this favor. Not me.

89 We now see that all this time he has been talking to Naom his wife, who is lying in bed with a book in her hand, ha listening to him without losing her place on the page. Eshel plugs his phone cable into an outlet. It comes to l Eshel smiles.

I haven't used it in months. Do they know it’s mine? NAOMI . I’1l call customer service tomorrow. From his POV, we see his screen as he scrolls passed the missed calls from Norman.

But I’m not complaining about that because I think he’s an embarrassing human being and he shouldn’t have been in your life in the first place.

dialogues.text: (placing his hand over his chest) Now you’re making that. lump feel worse. You really think I deceived him in some way?

NaoMt No. In fact, f yo must know - I did think it nig! t hurt Davidy. The last person in the world he wants a referral from, especially at Harvard, is Norman Oppenheimer. But I didn’t want to hurt Norman’s feelings and since I didn’t think anything would come of it anyway, yes, et it go. They remain in silence for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI
dialogues.text: (turning around and shutting off the light You’re in no position to judge me, Mr. Prime Minister. INT. ESHEL’S BEDROOM - LATER - ISRAEL 90 Eshel in his bed. He can’t sleep. It is that lump in his chest. We close in on his worried face. FADE OUT.

dialogues.text: Let me look into this.  97 98 99 85.
