dialogues.text: Norman looks down at his phone scrolling down his contact stroking his face, scratching his ear. He dials - PHILIP COHEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Philip is getting out of an elevator, waving good morning his co-workers as he makes his way to his office and spea to Norman.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Doesn’t look good for your guy. Do ou know who he is, the New York usinessman?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: If I did, is there any way we can help Eshel?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Careful. Don’t put your nose into this if you don’t have to... This kind of investigation brings the worst out of everyone. As Norman speaks, he looks out the window. From Norman’s POV, we see the SHTETL MAN pacing the sidew right outside the Starbucks, unapologetically ooking at Norman, as if he is waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: But what do you think? Does it sound serious? Philip enters a room full of people waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s serious. Bribery is tricky. Especially in Israel where you have the Mideastern mentality of giving baksheesh and cutting corners and a legal system run by tight-assed German yekkes. If they can prove he accepted a gift, he’s done. He could end up in jail... Gotta go. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So does Norman. He is confused. Outside, we still see the Shtetl man. Norman is contemplating something. He looks at the contac list on his phone.  100 86. INT. CAROL RASKIN’S OFFICE - DAY 100 We are in the United States Attorney's office in lower Manhattan. There are 5 LAWYERS in this room, one of them, the person charge, is CAROL RASKIN, who is speaking directly to-- Alex Green, sitting across her desk. Carol is holding a copy of the New York Times in her hand she disciplines Alex.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You have the president of the United States inquiring about an investigation that I don’t even know about! This is not the Middle East, Ms. Green! In this part of the world, there are rules. There are regulations. There are agreements between countries on how to obtain evidence in a criminal case... ecially if it has to do with a lester of a foreign country! How could I not know this investigation was going on??

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Because it’s not going on. Yet. It is a newspaper headline, not an investigation.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: So where are they getting this from? Is the Israeli police questioning an American citizen or not?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: As far as I understand, they’re still figuring out if they have enough information to make a proper request. The witness doesn’t even know he is a witness at this point.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (confused) Wait. You didn’t speak to this guy yet? Alex hesitates before she answers.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a simple question. Did you speak to him?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I did. Ona train. A casual conversation that lead me to make some inquiries and file a report. That is all it is right now. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A report. The Israeli prosecution is still considering whether or not to submit a request for legal assistance. But someone there leaked this to the Israeli press before I even had a chance RG speak to the witness.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Who is he? What’s his name? Your witness...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: He claims he is a friend of yours. Do you still want to know his name?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I'll find out sooner or later... Who is he? His name in Norman Oppenheimer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is exiting the Starbucks with his paper under his and his coffee in his hand. But then he stops in his steps. He thinks for a moment. H has an idea... INT. CAROL RASKIN’S OFFICE - DAY 102

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Norman Oppenheimer? Alex nods her head. Carol places the newspaper on her desk, leans back in her chair, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Norman Oppenheimer?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? Alex shakes her head. Carol loses her smile.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unbelievable. (takes a moment) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You're going to topple down a democratically elected, acting prime minister and jeopardize America’s long term foreign policy because of something Norman Oppenheimer told you on a train?? Alex remains silent. INT. STARBUCKS —- DAY 103 Norman is back in the Starbucks, waiting for the restroom he waits, he is restless. He seems excited about somethin Perhaps he is rehearsing a conversation in his head. INT. CAROL RASKIN’S OFFICE - DAY 104

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (deep breath Alright. I’m glad we had this meeting. No harm done. m going to call Bruce Schwartz Sad ter him there is no investigation involving an American citizen going on. End of story. False alarm. We can all relax. Carol looks up at Alex to see if she is understanding her But Alex’s expression is anything but relaxing.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t give me that look. Norman Oppenheimer is not a friend of mine. I know him like I know four million other people. I don’t even remember what the connection is. He knows a cousin of mine... He sends me e-mails... I don’t think I’ve ever responded to him. If he turns out to be a crook, I couldn’t care less. But trust me- Norman Oppenheimer might be a royal nudge, but he is not your villain. He’s a poor, jonely shmo trying to survive. And he is a pathological liar, in case you didn’t notice.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I don't think he is a villain either, but over the past three years he has been unusually generous toward the prime minister of Israel and has created an intricate network of people who benefit from the access he provides for them. In my part of the world - that kind of behavior warrants an investigation, Especially if he is a pathological liar... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Carol takes her point, but before she has a chance to respond, Alex's phone RINGS. ALEX (CONT’D Sorry. I'll shut it of As she reaches to shut off her phone, she sees the name o the screen: NORMAN OPPENHEIMER She shows the screen to Carol as it continues to ring.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Why is he calling you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I thought you said he doesn’t know about this.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: He doesn’t. Not from me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is now in the restroom, anxiously waiting for Alex pick up. He has balanced his coffee on the rim of the sin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. CAROL RASKIN’S OFFICE - AT THE SAME TIME 106

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Take the call. Put him on speaker. Alex places her phone on the desk and puts Norman on spea

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Alex Green!! This is Norman from the train. Norman Oppenheimer - I’ve been meaning to call... How are you? How have you been?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (her eyes locked on Carol's) I'm fine, Norman. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Fine, Fine. Can’t complain. I just got in from Chicago actually... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen, do you have a minute? You probably know why I’m calling.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I can guess, yes.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I know how discrete ou are, so if I'm imposing, feel ree to tell me it’s none of my business. I’m not going to ask you for the guy’s name, either... Unless you can tell me. Can you’ Alex looks at Carol for guidance. She seems just as cluel NORMAN (CONT’D Forget it. Forget it. I didn't ask. I respect your professionalism. But gest tell me one thing... You’re he one dealing with this investigation, right? This is your department, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Norman... Carol is signaling with her hand to Alex to let Norman go

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN ALEX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes... I’m sorry. Please continue...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I'll tell you why I’m calling. I hope it’s okay. I know this is delicate but I feel it is my duty. I think I can help you out. A pause for quizzical looks between Alex and Carol. Norman, who is hyper, inadvertently knocks his coffee ove It is on his pants, the floor, everywhere. There is an INDUSTRIAL MOP in the room. Norman tries to detach the mop from the BUCKET AND WRINGER as he speaks, it is stuck--

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is no secret that I’m on Eshel’s team. I support him. I love him. I think he is doing amazing things... but I was just thinking - whoever this person is, this unnamed businessman, I probably know him. Right? Maybe I can shed some light on whatever it is that happened and help you make sense of it. Another point of view for you to consider, that’s all I’m offering here. If it helps Eshel too, it is the least I can do... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Carol is completely bewildered by Norman’s tactics. Alex seems too shocked to say anything. And Norman, in the restroom, has finally detached the mop splashing soap-water all over himself and the room and toppling over the bucket. NORMAN (CONT’D) What do you say, Alex? Meet me for coffee. There is a reason why we met on that train. You never know... Right? You never know... Alex looks up at Carol for_her verdict. Reluctantly, Caro nods her head with approval.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: How is today at four? Come to my office in the consulate. Norman smiles at his reflection in the restroom mirror. H did it! He got his foot in.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Perfect. As he grabs a bunch of paper towels out of the dispenser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman, wet and disheveled, with his wet newspaper still under his arm, casually exits the restroom, ong his’ over puddle that has formed around the door, noddin is head apologetically to the 3 ANNOYED CUSTOMERS waiting outside We catch a glimpse of SHTETL MAN, now standing on line fo coffee. But Norman is too preoccupied to notice him. Norman is on his phone as he exits the Starbucks. INT. PHILIP’S OFFICE - DAY 108

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: (whispering) I can’t talk to you right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman walks down the avenue.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes you can. Meet me downstairs. I’m right around the corner from you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Did you find out who it is?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Better. I’m meeting the investigator who is in charge of the whole thing. Come downstairs. Give me five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Norman, I can’t... But Norman has hung up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. ENTRANCE TO PHILIP’S OFFICE BUILDING - DAY 110 Madison Ave. - busy, crowded mid-town sidewalks, and Norm waiting anxiously by the entrance to Philip’s office building. Norman sees Philip rushing out.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming down...

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: What are you doing? You're acting like a maniac. Look at you... Why are you getting involved? This thing is bad for Israel, bad for America, bad for Jews, bad for everybody. Step away...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: It is bad for everybody, that’s why I want to help...

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: How can you help? It’s a political war going on seven thousand miles from here. Eshel’s rivals found this cockamamie story and they’re going to use it to take him down. There is nothing you can_do about it, Don’t get involved. It is too 1g. Philip looks at Norman to see if his reasoning is enterin his head. It isn’t--

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Just tell me one thing. Hypothetically, if this guy, this businessman, came to you for advice. If he wanted you to represent him. What would you tell im? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Why? You want to approach him? It’s ad idea...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Maybe if we give him an gption that isn’t so harmful to Eshel. Philip looks at Norman, trying to figure out what his rea interest here is. Norman is looking back at him, waiting an answer.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I'd throw him out of my office. That’s what I’d do. I wouldn’t want anything to do with him. He is a threat to an acting prime minister. Even if it doesn’t end up having any criminal implication, apparently his dealings with Eshel are embarrassing enough so that his olitical rivals thin they can _ use im to hurt Eshel. Eshel’s people can’t ignore that. They have too much to lose... They’re going to strike back. Dig up everything they can find on this guy. The FBI will get involved... No matter how you ook at it, this guy is fucked. And you want to avoid him like the plague.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: What if you knew him and he was asking you for help? Philip takes this in. Suddenly it dawns on him - Norman m be the unnamed businessman. He carefully considers his ne words.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Are you saying something I don’t want to hear? What are you saying? NORMAN ; I’m not saying anything. I’m just asking.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Norman, listen to me. Whoever this unnamed businessman is, he is in very serious trouble. And he needs e@ very careful about what he says now and who he speaks to. Norman thinks this over for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I’m only asking if there is a legal way to defuse this? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I’m meeting the investigator, and I find out who this man is, I want to be able to offer him something. Let’s think creatively. Philip can’t conceal his panic. He takes a step back.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I can offer him anything. This man needs a very good criminal lawyer. Don’t be creative. And don’t meet this investigator. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you do that? Norman seems confused. But he nods his head. Philip backs away, verifying with his eyes that Norman ha internalized his instructions. He disappears into the building. Norman is pacing the street with his phone in his hand. I bigger than him. And he can’t resist it... Across the street, we see THE SHTETL MAN, but Norman does notice him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eshel is in his seat on the parliament floor, listening t absorbing - a scathing speech delivered with much pathos RON MAOR. We focus on Eshel's face, on Duby’s face, on Hanna’s face they are forced to hear sentences like: RON MAOR. We‘ve seen politicians with no backbone gain power before - that is not new... We’ve seen political opportunists who grossly distort e@ will of the citizens who voted them into office, only to shamefully gain favor in the eyes of foreign rulers in service o interests that are not our own - that is not new either. But never in our nation’s history has a man of such low moral standing, so spiritually empty, so unapologetical y hedonistic, selfish I dare say - been ina position to do so much damage to our people and our nation, as the man I'm pointing to right now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hanna’s phone is blinking. She looks at her screen. It is NORMAN. She shows it to Duby, who is standing next to her by the door to the parliament hall. Duby shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: No. Not today. I can’t deal with Norman.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: But if I don’t answer he will drive me crazy all day. He’ll_ call ever three minutes. It’s easier to jus answer.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Alright, but keep it short. Don’t let him get involved in anything. Hanna steps out as she answers her phone.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Norman. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is walking and talking on his phone. Hyper and excited.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Forget me. How are you??

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Busy as usual.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Any chance you can connect me to the prime minister or to Duby?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I'm afraid they're...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Wait, before you say no. Listen to what I have to sa they’ re going to want to hear t is. m meeting with the woman who is in charge of this investigation that is going on. Her name is Alex Green. She’s a good friend of mine and she agreed to meet me today at four. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m going to try and get as much information as I can, but if Duby wants to brief me before this meeting, that might make the meeting more productive... Hanna doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Norman, I don’t think it is such a good idea for you...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Will you give them this message? Tell them I’m meeting with Alex Green today. They can use me however they want. I’m like a puppet in their hands. It’s a riendly conversation, off the record... She’s a good friend. I've known her for years. My wife used to babysit her...

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Norman. Hold on a second. Just wait on the line.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CHOCOLATIER
dialogues.text: Norman stops by the CHOCOLATIER where he saw Eshel in the beginning of the film while he waits. We see his POV look into the shop: beautiful, colorful chocolate treats. Rich chocolate and direct access to power - his heart is palpitating with excitement. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (to his phone) Duby! I’m so happy to hear your voice. How are you? What’s going on? Can you tell me who...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Duby walking out of the parliament hall with Hanna phone, fuming. He enters a SMOKING AREA closed off with g walls, where he can finally raise his voice.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Shut up, Norman.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Shut up and listen to what I’m saying to you. I don’t want you meeting anybody on our behalf. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DUBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Creating the impression that in someway you are connected to our office is a severe punishable crime. Do you understand me? SILENCE. Hanna is watching Duby on the other side of the glass.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to make sure I am clear about this. Stop using the prime minister’s name. Just stop. Don’t do it anymore. He is not your friend and you do not have an relationship with him. I forbid you to meet with this woman. Do you understand what I’m saying? Answer me. Norman's eyes are focused on a tray with beautiful NUT CO TRUFFLES. Then the focus changes - reflected in the shop window, No notices the THE SHTETL MAN standing across the street. He realizes that this man has been following him around sinc first saw him through the Starbucks window. After a pause.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Good. Goodbye Norman. Duby hangs up, exits the smoking area and hands the phone back to Hanna as if the phone itself is contaminated.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Enough. Don’t answer his calls anymore. He is cut off. No more. Just the thought of him talking to an investigator makes me want to vomit. And find out who Alex Green is... Something is bothering Hanna.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I’m not sure it was such a good idea to insult Norman that way... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: UBY
dialogues.text: That’s the “problem with these Normans - they’re a double edged sword - if you keep them in the loop, you become more and more dependant on them until they gradually own you. - if you cut them off, they blackmail you for the rest of your life.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I think he is just trying to help. If you would have told him nicely that he would be helping us if he didn’t speak to anyone, I think that would have been more effective.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to talk about Norman anymore. Lets find out who this businessman is. I need a name! In a day every newspaper in the world ill want to know who this man is and we need to be prepared... He walks back into the parliament hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Ron Maor’s speech still in the background, we see Du hand a SMALL FOLDED NOTE to an USHER who brings it to Esh

dialogues.speaker: RON MAOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How will we explain this tragicy historical accident to our children and grandchildren? How, I ask you? By. preventing it. By voting against this dangerous agreement, masquerading as a peace treaty. Eshel receives the note. He opens it. It reads: “WHO IS HE?” Eshel looks over_at Duby, signaling with his hands and sincere eyes - “I have no idea”.

dialogues.speaker: RON MAOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Giving in to our enemy's /every, la last demand is not peace!! It’s calle

dialogues.speaker: LOSING
dialogues.text: Heckling and uproar in the room! Duby exchanges a final concerned glance with Eshel before he leaves the parliame hall, pulling Hanna with him.  117 99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tight shot on Duby and Hanna.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Call Norman. Tell him you want to apologize for how I spoke to him. Then tell him we know who the guy is and we are not worried. This unnamed businessman has so many skeletons in his closet, sex offenses, tax fraud, money laundering, the man is a total mess = no prosecutor in the world would dare put him on the witness stand. Hanna is confused.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: You know who he is? Who is he??

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Just do what I said. And make it sound as if you are telling this to him in confidence, behind my back. Make him swear not to repeat what he just heard. Hanna gets it.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: You think he'll repeat it all to the investigator.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: He’1l be trying to prove to her that he knows what’s going on. And not only to her. He’ "ut spread the word all over the place and he’1l probably exaggerate it so that it sounds even worse. Call him. Make him believe there is nothing to worry about. His beloved prime minister is perfectly fine. Go. Make the call. But how do you A now he is going to meet with that investigator? You told him not to. Duby smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: Just call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is going down the escalator towards the Subway in Grand Central Station. He is on his phone-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: He did? --You know who he is, the businessman?? --...I can’t tell you how relieved I am to hear you say this. Thank you, Hanna. Please tell Duby that I understand his situation completely. And if there is anything he needs me to do, he knows I’m here for him and for the rime minister. -- That’s what I ike to_ hear. The prime minister is a very lucky man to have you on his side, Hanna. You know that, right? Really, this kind of loyalty is so rare. It’s sacred. I hope you know that... --Of course. Say no more. My lips are sealed. Good luck, Hanna. By now Norman has stepped off the escalator and pulled ou his METRO CARD. But instead of going through the turnstil he stops in his steps. Invigorated with a new sense of purpose, Norman changes h mind about taking the subway. He turns back to get on the escalator going back up to Street level. As he heads up, he sees the Shtetl man on the downward escalator. THEIR EYES MEET as they pass each other. The Shtetl man immediately turns around and heads up agai the direction of the escalator, so not to lose Norman. At this point Norman understands that he is being followe He quickly cuts through the crowd towards the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman exits Grand Central into the busy street, startled We see Norman’s POV - New Yorkers of all ages, color, cla and ethnicity - but no shtetl man. Then he sees him exit the station, casually walking away. Norman runs after him.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Hay. You. Hold on a second.

dialogues.speaker: SHTETL MAN
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. You. Why are you following me? What do you want? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHTETL MAN
dialogues.text: First of all, nice to meet you. Srul Katz. Srul pulls out of his pocket a pack of BUSINESS CARDS wra in a rubber band. He wants to give one to Norman, but Nor steps back.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No. Excuse me. Don’t give me that. I don’t want it. Stop following me around. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: SRUL
dialogues.text: Why are you angry? Don’t be angry. I’m not ollowing you around. By sheer coincidence I happen to be going where you are goin What do you want me to do? I apo ogize. I’m sorry... Norman looks at the man, evaluating him. He is unkempt, o the heavy side, with some stains on his shirt and an old, worn-out hat on his head. Norman nods his head in disbelief and is about to turn aw

dialogues.speaker: SRUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But if we’re alread taiking, If I can take a few minutes of your time, I’m glad to finally feet you in person. You’re the Eshel guy, right? Oppenheimer. Maybe Zvi Fink mentioned me to you.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: How do you know Zvi?

dialogues.speaker: SRUL
dialogues.text: Zvi and I are very close. My wife ractically grew up in his parents ouse. I’m helping him out with a few things. Actually I’m seeing him later tonight. You should come say hello. I know he’d be very happy to see you. Norman seems confused. He just looks at Srul, not saying word.

dialogues.speaker: SRUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? You look shaken up. How can I help you? What do you need?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: What do I need??

dialogues.speaker: SRUL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Give me the honor of helping you out. You’re a choshuv e’man. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SRUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me walk with you. Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: To the Israeli consulate on Second Ave. Srul puts his arm in Norman's and begins to walk with him Norman is too surprised by this strange gesture to resist They walk together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman and Srul turn the corner together.

dialogues.speaker: SRUL KATZ
dialogues.text: So, who’s the guy? Do you know who he is, the New York businessman?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: If I knew, would I tell you?

dialogues.speaker: SRUL KATZ
dialogues.text: I heard a rumor. But I was sworn to secrecy.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t believe what you hear.

dialogues.speaker: SRUL KATZ
dialogues.text: You obviously know more than me, but whoever it is, one thing is for sure. It’s a conspiracy. They found a way to assassinate Eshel, without actually killing him. Norman thinks about this for a second.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t bury Eshel yet. Trust me. He’s not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: SRUL KATZ
dialogues.text: Why, what do you know?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I can’t go into details, but let’s just say this unnamed | businessman is... He’s a nobody , a parasite, trying to extort the prime minister. He is the ewest of the low... He made up a story. The whole thing is made up. Eshel doesn’t even know the man. Norman stops. He is suddenly having a hard time stabilizi his breathing. Srul notices Norman’s stress and waits patiently for Norman to recompose. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NORMAN (CONT’D) I_really shouldn’t say anything else. Srul faces Norman with a sympathetic look. They continue walking in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at the consulate.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I think I’m okay from here on. Thank you. I appreciate it. SRUL KATZ oo, You sure? I’m happy to go in with you.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No. That’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: SRUL KATZ
dialogues.text: I can wait for you outside...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No. Thank you. I’m good from here. Really, thank you very much. I appreciate it. Srul pulls out his business cards and hands one to Norman Norman looks at it. It reads: “KATZ STRATEGIES, INC.”

dialogues.speaker: SRUL KATZ
dialogues.text: Call me, if you ever need anything. Anything at all. I’m happy to help. Zel gezunt. Norman nods his head, perplexed by the whole encounter. As Norman walks into the consulate, he turns back to see Srul Katz is still standing there, smiling, waving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we see is the back of Norman’s head and his somewhat distorted reflection in the ONE WAY MIRROR that separates from the security guard behind the window.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (to the intercom) My name is Norman Oppenheimer. I have an appointment with Alex Green. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Please empty your pockets into the tray. A tray is pushed out from the bottom of the window. Norma pulls out his wallet, keys change Srul Katz’s business card, and his EPIPEN. He plac he items on the tray. SECURITY GUARD'S VOICE (CONT’D) Do you have a cell phone?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Please shut it off and put it in the tray as well.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Will you give it back to me?

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD'S VOICE
dialogues.text: When you leave. Norman places his phone on the tray. The phone and the re of the items are swallowed into the one-way mirror divide SECURITY GUARD'S VOICE (CONT’D) Please enter, collect your possessions on the tray, and follow the yellow line to the third door on your right. A LOUD BUZZER IS HEARD, UNLOCKING THE DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a two door system. The second door won’t open unt the first door is closed. But Norman is afraid to have bo doors closed at the same time, so he keeps his foot in th first door. The walls of this small, isolated security booth are all dark, one-way mirrors.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD VOICE
dialogues.text: Mr. Oppenheimer, you need to close the first door for the second door to open. Before he removes his foot from the door - Norman looks b outside - The glare of daylight is strong and blinding, but Norman pretty sure Srul Katz is still standing there, smiling. We sense that Norman is recognizing something in Srul’s f as if he has seen this smile before. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But the door closes. And locks. Before Norman can put his finger on why and where Srul is familiar to him. Norman presses his face against the one-way mirror to try see what is behind it, but all he sees is his own distort reflection. Norman panics and tries to reopen the door.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (to the one-way mirror) You know what, I forgot something. I’m canceling’ my meeting. Can I have my phone back? No response. NORMAN (CONT’D) (knocking on the window) Hello? Anybody there? I’m not going in. Can I have my stuff back? Hello... Hello... please, open the door! Open the door! A LOUD BUZZER IS HEARD. The second door unlocks. Norman opens the second door and goes through. The door shuts on lens, creating a BLACK SCREEN. We hear over black:

dialogues.speaker: ALEX'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It’s Okay. Come.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: They told me not to meet with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the end of the work day, Manhattan at its most crow hour. Everything is a blur, except for Norman, walking the stre lost in a daze, with his phone in one hand, and an ENVELO in the other. We close in on Norman’s face. His eyes are BLOODSHOT AND SWOLLEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We_see the yellow line on the floor, as Norman’s feet are walking down the corridor. At the end of the yellow line, we see Alex waiting at the end of this naked, fluorescent lit corridor.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Who? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The prime minister’s office. Duby. I don’t want to upset them. This was a mistake. He’1ll know I’m here. We cut to a closer shot of Alex’s grim face. NORMAN'S VOICE (CONT’D) Please, I should really go. I apologize, I respect you very much, but I°-can’t do this. This is serious. I shouldn’t have called you.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It is good that you called. And I’m lad you are here. Please, sit own. I want this conversation to be straightforward and honest. Do you think you can do that? Cut to a shot of:

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to make things worse for Eshel. We see a FLASH OF ALEX sitting behind a desk in her offic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Norman’s face. He stops walking. He can hardly breathe Rushed New Yorkers walking around him pay no attention to him. Then a shot of:

dialogues.speaker: ALEX'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I’ve spent the last few months trying to find out more about you. Where you come from, what you do, who your friends are. your family... Your financial situation. A FLASH of Alex offering a GLASS OF WATER toward the came Then a shot of:

dialogues.speaker: ALEX'S VOICE
dialogues.text: But what I’ve discovered is very strange. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALEX'S VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everybody seems to know who you are. But nobody knows anything about you. Even people who say they have known you for years. A FLASH of Alex in the office pulling out a FOLDER FULL O DOCUMENTS. Then a shot of: UNDERWATER PHOTOGRAPHY OF EXOTIC FISH AND COLORFUL CORAL.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX'S VOICE
dialogues.text: For instance, I wasn’t able to verify that you have a daughter, or that you were ever married. Were you? Do you have a daughter?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Why are you collecting information about me? INT. ALEX’S OFFICE 132 And now finally we see Alex in her office, in sync, speak directly to Norman. Over her head, on the office walls, we see FRAMED PICTURE with images of the Israeli Tourism Ministry's version of Middle Eastern bliss:

dialogues.speaker: --THE FISH, --THE DEAD SEA,
dialogues.text: they are all framed pictures hanging on the wall behind A Our focus changes to Alex’s face.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Because I think the kind of relationship you’‘ve established with the prime minister of Israel is illegal. I think it is corrupt. INT. MEN’S CLOTHING BOUTIQUE - DAY A133 A shot of Eshel reflected in the mirrors of the fitting r from the scene in the beginning of the film, as he tries the SUIT. Eshel exchanges a glance with Norman. Norman is smiling, but by now we know him well enough to sense a nervousness in his eyes and the itch around his n WE HEAR THE SOUND OF A MOVING TRAIN, taking us to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We flash back to the scene on the train from Washington t New York. Alex and Norman are reflected in the train wind Their faces are lit by a passing dight from outside the moving train creating a strobing effect. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Do you have a specific area of expertise? Can you explain to me how your business works? If it is not too complicated... I’m curious.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Have you ever played rummikub?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: My mother used to_hate playing with me, because I would mess up the board, break up existing sets and try to create new ones with whatever lousy pieces I had on my rack. Sometimes I'd mess it up so bad, there was no way to put everything back. My mother would go crazy. She’d say, if you don’t have a specific, simple move, just pick up a tile and let the game continue to_the next player. But usually, all I needed to finish my turn, is one little Joker. That’s all you need. If you have the Joker, you can afford to take some risks. Somehow, with a Joker in your hand, all the tiles fall into place.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I still don’t understand...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: That’s what I do. I’m the Joker. As soon as you put me in the game, things work out. Here, let me show you. Norman refers to the yellow legal pad with the diagrams h had drawn for her. It takes us back to: INT. ALEX’S OFFICE - DAY 134 We see Alex’s LEGAL PAD on the table with the diagrams an names that Norman wrote down on that train ride. Our view tilts up from the diagram to Alex's face.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: The unnamed New York businessman - You are that man, Norman. You are our witness.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH to Norman walking in the busy street. He closes his eyes and shakes his head, as if to block away what Alex i saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is looking around at the forest of human encounter frozen in time. At once, everyone in the room TURNS TO LO DIRECTLY A HIM. We see Norman, in a panic, clutch his EPIPEN. INT. ALEX’S OFFICE - DAY C135

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: We can subpoena you. You have no choice. This does not come naturally for Alex, but she reaches ou and touches Norman’s trembling hand. Norman needs this gesture. He allows her to keep her fingers over his hand afew gcconds. By now, his face, his eyes, are EXTREMELY I ED.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I have to leave now. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You need to hear what I have to say. We are arranging an early deposition for you tomorrow. I gan’ t force you to stay here now ut... Alex has an ENVELOPE in her free hand. She places it on t table in front of Norman. Norman pulls his hand away and gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is your official notice...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Do they know it is me?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Duby, Hanna... Eshel. Do they know it 1s me?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: If they don’t already, they will soon.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: What will they do to me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: If you cooperate with us tomorrow. If you testify and speak truthfully about sSverythang ¥ you've experience we will protect you from self incrimination. It will be about him. Not about you. There is an ITCH that Norman feels around his collar bone scratches it violently, without any awareness that he is doing this.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: But what will Eshel do to me?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: They will try to convince the court and the public that you are an unreliable witness. That will most likely be their defense. Norman nods his head. Alex hands him the NOTICE. Norman hesitates for a brief moment, then he takes the envelope. Right before he exits the room--

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Norman turns around and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is standing on the median of Park Ave. in Midtown, looking down at the ENVELOPE. He is frozen stiff in the middle of one of the busiest spots in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Eshel’s shocked face. The camera pulls back to reveal Duby whispering into Eshe ear, while Eshel is sitting at the center of a room, wait for a cabinet meeting to begin. We see Hanna standing near by, holding her phone in her f Eshel wants to say something, but in this setting he can’ say a word. He looks over at Duby Duby steps back, out of the light. A SHADOW falls over Duby’ s face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cartoons, caricatures - of Norman in relation to the prim minister, under the sound of Duby’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Right now, very few people know who Norman Oppenheimer is, but in a few days everyone will want to. We have an opportunity to brand him... First caricature: Norman is a rich uncle offering a lolli to an innocent, child-like prime minister on a street cor

dialogues.speaker: DUBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...-To introduce him to the world in a way that will disqualify him as witness and at the same time paint the prime minister as an innocent victim. Second caricature: Norman as a stray mutt latching onto t prime minister’s leg as he tries to shake him off with an olive branch on his way up to receiving the Nobel peace prize.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY,, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If our leader is a victim... We are all victims... Third Caricature: Norman is the sore toe on the foot of a aching prime minister portrayed as Atlas with a globe weighing heavily on his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: How am I victim? We are too powerful to be victims...

dialogues.speaker: DUBY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Never say that... It is not true. Fourth caricature: A Cinderella-like situation. Norman, w a devious smirk on his face, trying to fit a shoe on Eshe foot. Eshel appearing as a delicate, beautiful princess. INT. PRIME MINISTER’S OFFICE - NIGHT - ISRAEL 138 On Eshel’s face sitting behind his desk. He looks devasta

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: You are Mr. Peace right now. The press will be on your side - Nobody wants to see our peace efforts go down the drain because of the fantasies of some Jewish macher. We need to portray him as a delusional name-dropper who has been sucking your blood for years. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DUBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need to say this in a clear way, not only because it is necessary, but because it is true. Eshel exchanges a look with Hanna.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: There must be another way. Norman is a friend. A very generous friend. I can’t hurt him.

dialogues.speaker: DUBY
dialogues.text: It is not about you and him. It is much bigger than whatever personal feelings you might have right now. And bigger than the pain it brings on any one person. Eshel is shaking his head, he needs more...

dialogues.speaker: DUBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Norman Oppenheimer is a threat to our national interests. You_need to treat him like you would any other threat. This is not your choice. It is your duty. It sinks in. SLOW DISSOLVE FROM ESHEL’S FACE TO NORMAN, STANDING AT:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is standing on the median of Park Ave., waiting fo the LIGHT to change. He takes a deep breath. He_ sees A MAN ON A BIKE in the middle of the street, balancing himself on his bike with both feet on the pedal he waits for the light to change. The biker is in his 40s, wearing a business suit, tie and helmet on his head. He is determined to stay on his bike the duration of the light without putting his feet down. Norman’s PHONE RINGS. He looks at the screen. It is PHILI COHEN. INT. PHILIP’S OFFICE - NIGHT 140 Philip is on the phone. They are silent for a moment. Finally.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I took your advice. I didn’t g° to the meeting. I’m stepping bac like you said. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Philip doesn’t know how to respond. Across from his desk, a shelf, one of the many framed pictures we see of Philip with different sports celebrities and politicians, is a PICTURE OF ESHEL, PHILIP and NORMAN, taken at the Aipac convention. Finally—-

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I’m proud of you. Good move. Another beat of silence.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you there, Norman? Norman's eyes are fixed on the BIKER as he skillfully maneuvers his body on the bike to keep from falling, with advancing into the busy intersection.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I’m fine. I think my body is reacting to something I ate. I'll take a Benadryl. I’1l be fine...

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Good. Good. ...I wish _I could be more helpful... but, I don’t...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) I’m a good swimmer, Philip. Don’t worry. As long as my head is above water...

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: You are a good swimmer. That’s for sure.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: You have been a very big help, Philip. Thank you. I appreciate it. Thank you. Philip is silent. He can hardly breathe. His face is red. Norman hangs up. Finally the LIGHT CHANGES and the biker pedals forward wi the rest of the traffic. Norman hails a cab. EXT. RABBI BLUMENTHAL’S SYNAGOGUE - NIGHT 141 Norman exits the cab in front of the synagogue. He tries to open the door to the synagogue but it is lock (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He RINGS THE BUZZER. There is no response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman walks around the building into the narrow alley wh there is a decorative window into the main sanctuary. Norman climbs on a garbage can and peeks through. The sight of the dimly lit empty sanctuary is comforting Norman, so he just stands there with his face pressed aga the window. Then: MAN’S VOICE Can I help you? Norman turns around. It is Rabbi Blumenthal.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Rabbi!

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: You! What are you doing here??

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I need to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: You need to sign those escrow papers, that’s what you need. Do you realize we are going to lose all our pledges if this anonymous donor doesn’t come through, not to mention this building, and my job! Why aren’ t you answering my phone s?? Norman, still standing on the garbage can, says nothing. Rabbi Blumenthal understands what Norman’s silence means. k RABBI BLUMENTHAL (CONT’D) Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I’m working on it.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: Fuck!! He kicks the garbage can. Norman falls to the ground! Rabbi Blumenthal kicks one of the garbage bags right into Norman’s face. RABBI BLUMENTHAL (CONT’D) I should have known. I should have known not to trust you. I should have known. It’s my fault. What do I do now?? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Norman, on the ground, covered in garbage, just looks at with nothing to say.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Was there a donor? At any point? Ever? Or did you just make him up?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I thought I had someone. And I might still have him. But it is not a sure thing... They look at each other. When Norman finally tells the tr there is something disarming about his demeanor.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BLUMENTHAL
dialogues.text: Then why did you tell us you had a donor? Why would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. The rabbi shakes his head in despair and walks away. Norman sits himself up and leans against the wall, removi pieces of PICKLED HERRING from his coat and face. Then-- HIS PHONE RINGS! Norman locates his phone and looks at his screen: ESHEL

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE CELL
dialogues.text: Norman takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: EXT. ESHEL’S PRIVATE RESIDENCE - SUNRISE - ISRAEL 143 Eshel, with his phone to his ear, is in his private garde The sun is coming up. Norman finally answers, but doesn’t say a word.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: Is that you, Norman? SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Norman, are you there?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Is it safe for us to talk?

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: It probably isn’t. But there is something I need to tell you before the lawyers and PR people take over. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I am speaking to you now as Micha Eshe not as the prime minister of Israel. (he pauses ) I’m sorry. I’m sorry for what is about to happen to you. In the next couple of days you are going to hear me saying things that I don’t really believe. Things about you. And it will hurt. It will hurt both of us. But the only reason I will be saying these things is because there are hundreds of thousands of lives at stake. The enemies of peace have decided to step all over you on their way to behead me. It is a terrible price to pay, but Norman, I can’t let them win. We can’t let them win. SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you accept my apology, Norman? Do you forgive me? 116. 143 Norman looks up to the sliver of sky that can be seen through the two buildings on either side of the

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: History is full of anonymous heroes who helped bring | civilization to its greatest achievements. While I, Micha Eshel, am asking you for forgiveness from the bottom of my heart, the prime minister of Israel is eternally grateful to you for being one of those heroes. The day I walk up to that podium to sign the peace treaty, you will see a very specific expression on my face. Know that I will be thinking of you... Norman Oppenheimer. narrow alley. There is a tense silence on both sides of the line. Final

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I will never betray you.

dialogues.speaker: ESHEL
dialogues.text: I love you, Norman. Thank you. Eshel hangs up. He turns to face-- DUBY who has been standing on the other side of all along. They exchange a look that says - “It’s done”. the garden (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then Eshel takes his private phone and throws it into a s DECORATIVE FISH POND on his way back into the residence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman gets up and cleans himself from the garbage that i still stuck to his clothing. laces the garbage cans back where they belong, before he walks away. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dramatic view of dense Manhattan rooftops before dawn. The streets are still empty. Norman crosses a deserted and freezing street into Centra Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As in the first sequence of the film, this is the hour of fanatics. Norman is sitting on the same bench, watching them pass b their futuristic winter sportswear. He sees Bill Kavish finishing his run and finding a spot his stretches. Bill sees Norman. Norman approaches.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Good morning, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Way do you do this? Why do you ave this way? Why can’t anything ever be simple with you?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Who says simple is good? Bill looks at Norman. Strangely, Norman’s answer is actua quite - simple. NORMAN (CONT’D) I have a business opportunity that will interest Jo.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: No, you don’t. Whatever it is, it is too small. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: But it’s your job to listen to me anyway, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Jo Wilf doesn’t want to_hear your name or see your face. Listening to you is not part of my job. No. Definitely not now, with your friend in trouble... Norman nods his head, looks at Bill stretch his groin. He turns around and walks away. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait. Norman stops.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm listening. Out of respect , to my father. You knew him, didn’t you? Norman nods his head. But before any sentimentality settl in--

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What have you got?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: If you knew with one hundred percent certainty that the witness who is threatening to topple down. prime minister Eshel will never testify, would you know how to make money with that information? Bill is intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Del epends where and how I got the ormation and if I can verify it... You_realize that you are not a very reliable source, right?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Put me in a room with Jo Wilf. I'll give him the certainty he needs. Bill is hesitating. NORMAN (CONT’D) Think about it. Do the numbers. Come up with something. You have till eight AM to call me. Otherwise, I take it to Arthur Taub.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What’s your fee? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: If this works out, I want Jo Wilf to donate seven million anonymously to a charity of my choice. Norman walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York is waking UP. Commuters are exiting the subway stations, flooding the streets. Shops are opening. Street vendors are setting up for the Norman is strolling on the sidewalk, in a pace and world his own. For the first time in this film, he seems - tranquil. An innocent looking, perfectly standard NYC, (NUTS 4 NUTS NUT VENDOR enters Norman’s POV. It is a cold morning, the OWNER of the nut-stand, wrapped his puffy winter coat, engulfed in the roasting Smoke, acknowledges Norman who is looking down into the differen types of sugar coated nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are outside the Brooklyn Diner on 57th St. Through one the windows we see Norman and Jo Wilf sitting across from each other in a booth. We can’t hear them, but we see that while Norman is explaining his idea, he is writing his usual diagrams on NAPKIN, names, numbers and a scheme of lines connecting t all. At a certain point, he hands the napkin to Jo. Jo lo at it. He seems impressed. They and shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman points at the sugar coated, roasted peanuts. phe vendor scoops a bagful and hands Norman the warm pape ag.

dialogues.speaker: VENDOR
dialogues.text: Two dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is walking with the bag of nuts in his hand. Before he enters Bryant Park, he pulls his EPIPEN out of pocket. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He looks at the EpiPen for a brief moment before he - thr it into a WATER DRAIN by the entrance to the park

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
